August 17th, 1949.

Bernard F. Neary, Esq.
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As instructed in your wire of July 22nd, 1949 I contacted Wynn's Sawmill and had them ship me sixty bale of shavings for the insulation of the walls in the Ft; Rae Indian Day School. These shavings were delivered to me in Yellowknife last week and I have covered this purchase with Voucher #83.

Enclosed is the Voucher and Invoices for payment when a purchase order has been obtained.

These shavings will go forward by barge from here as soon as weather permits and the cost of freight will be vouchered through in the usual manner at that time.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Yellowknife, N.W.T.
August 18th, 1949.

Mr. B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Ref. Your telegram, date Aug. 17th, 1949.

Voucher for payment of shavings, purchased from Wynn's Sawmill, forwarded to your office Aug. 17th, 1949. The lime will be purchased at Yellowknife and a voucher sent to your office for payment.

Accountable advance received at the Bank of Commerce Yellowknife and as soon as work completed at Ft. Rae an accounting will be forwarded to your office.

The wood for the Ft. Rae Indian Day School is being cut and brought into town by barge. As a number of Natives are doing the work the Hudson's Bay Co. advances them food and clothing and once the wood has been delivered will pay all those engaged and send us the account for the total amount which in this case is $700.00. When the account is rendered by the Hudson's Bay I will voucher it through your office and no accountable advance will be necessary for the wood.

Repairs to Ft. Rae school will be starting tomorrow and I expect them to continue for approximately six weeks.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Wirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

310 Percy St., Ottawa, Ontario

During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the school term I believe it worth while to report on my observations at each point.

On September 22nd, I proceeded to Fort Rae to check on progress of repairs to this building. This work is nearing completion and a very good job has been obtained. The entire building has been insulated and the second story as well. This gives a manual training room for future use. The first floor has been divided into two with all old partitions removed, giving two good class rooms. The dividing partition is movable and the school will now make a good hall. All walls of first floor have been lined with gyprock wallboard and painted. Part of the second story has been lined as well, but there was a shortage of material and this will be obtained next year when the work can be completed. This gives a very good fireproof interior and very durable.

The whole interior has been painted including the ceiling. The windows, which just arrived by last boat of the season, are being put in and when the teacher returns from his holidays, the building should be complete ready for school.

The two new oil stoves have arrived as well as fuel oil, all noon lunch materials and the teachers ration have been put into Fort Rae on the last boat.

I expect to pick up the carpenter by plane before the middle of October and will then pay all wages and incidentals and send an accounting to your office.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last term and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

Dear Sir:

The alterations and repairs to the Ft. Rae School have now been completed and the balance of the accountable advance as well as the statement of expenditures is enclosed herewith.

The following work was completed by Mr. James Cull and two Indian helpers.

(1) Outside walls from ground level to top sill have been insulated with shavings.
(2) Ceiling of second storey completely insulated with Gyproc wool bats.
(3) First floor class rooms have walls lined with gyproc wallboard and bottom four feet of back wall protected with plywood.
(4) Sectional partition divides the building into two good class rooms. This partition can be removed if it is desirable to make the building into one room for any purpose.
(5) All interior partitions that formerly existed were removed as well as the old stair way.
(6) Temporary stairway erected on outside of building to second floor.
(7) Outside walls and roof painted.
(8) Class rooms completely painted both walls and ceiling.
(9) New and extra windows put in complete with storm sash.
(10) Two oil stoves installed and tested.
(11) Small porch over door put on for winter use.

The above work was done between August 20th. and October 13th. Mr. Cull returning to Yellowknife on the latter date.

In this district it has been the policy of the Dept. of Public Works to pay their foreman carpenter at the rate of $1.50 per hour and to deduct $1.25 a day for board. The DPW supply this board at whatever it costs and they absorb the difference.

At Ft. Rae there are no places to eat and at the start we were able to get a woman to cook for $1.50 per day while we were to supply the food. This lasted for one month and then the carpenter was able to stay with the R.C.M. Police and we continued to supply his food while they made no charge for any work they did in preparing any of his meals. There is no doubt we received cheaper board this way than through any other arrangement.

In order to get carpenters into places like Ft. Rae we have to fly them in and out. I took the carpenter in when I was making a flight and CP Airlines brought him out on one of their regular runs. I paid this fare out of the standing advance.

Don Lafferty and Alex McKenzie who are both Treaty Indians with two dependents were hired as helpers and as both boarded at home no deductions were made from their pay for this.

At all these out-of-the-way places we are forced to pay the Indians some of their wages as they work, otherwise they will not be able to feed themselves and their families. With this in mind...
arrangements were made with the Hudson's Bay Co. to advance money as the work progressed and that I would make the pay cheques for the Indians payable to the Hudson's Bay for the amount advanced. This will account for the pay cheques being made out as they are, with the extra amount due the workers paid directly to them at the end of the work.

If we do not arrange for wages of Indians to be paid this way it would never be possible to get a Native to work for more than a few days before he would quit.

Unemployment Insurance stamps and Revenue stamps for all cheques were paid for in cash and cheques were made payable to myself for the amounts.

Receiver General Cheques were made out for Income tax deducted from James Cull, Board deducted from James Cull, Employees share of Unemployment Insurance deducted and the unexpended balance of the advance sent to me here.

The repairs that were undertaken at this school have, I am sure, made a very good small two room school out of what was an old store. The walls were formerly covered with paper and everything was dirty from smoke and age, it being impossible for any teacher to make it cheerful. As there was a good frame to work from we now have what I would consider is a good two room school and with the addition of combination porch and cloakroom with wash rooms for the winter months and possibly put the building on a low cement foundation this school would make an ideal manual training building at such time as a new school may be erected. As the building is on solid rock it would last for many years if a small wall is put in.

I am quite sure that the building has been put into as good condition as possible with the materials available at Rae. It will be noted that a limited amount of extra building supplies were purchased as instructed in your telegram of August 17th. These supplies as well as lime used in shavings have been vouchered through for payment from Ottawa.

The unloading of freight and hauling from Frank's Channel was made necessary by the very late delivery of windows for the school, fuel oil and some other extras. The Northern Transportation Co. could not get within six or eight miles of Rae due to low water and we were forced to hire a local man with a power scow. The Hudson's Bay paid this man and sent the accounts here for payment.

I trust this accounting is satisfactory and that all the necessary information has been included.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Establishment of Church of England Indian Day School at Aklavik, Northwest Territories.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty-two Indian children of school age at Aklavik, in the Fort Norman Indian Agency, Northwest Territories, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch has agreed with the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs to conduct a day school at Aklavik for the education of Indian, half-breed and white children;

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Ottawa, December 30, 1946.

Dr. J. P. Harvey, Indian Agent,
Aklavik, North West Territories.

It is understood that these two residential schools are bringing in day school students from the local villages and having them attend school along with the residential school pupils.

We are now informed that this is providing too heavy a load upon the teachers at these schools. At a recent meeting of officials of the Northwest Territories Bureau and Indian Affairs Branch, it was decided to open day schools at each of the residential school plants. The Department is willing to pay for teachers and to provide such extra classroom equipment and materials as are required. It is therefore our intention to pay for one teacher at each of the two residential schools on a temporary basis until a proper day school can be erected. I am sending extra copies of this letter to the Principals of both schools concerned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR OF LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Director.

Attention: Colonel Neary,

Attached hereto is copy of report dated April 8th from District Engineer W. J. Johnston regarding the installation of an electric generator at Fort Good Hope for use in the two-classroom school and teacher's quarters being constructed there for your Branch by this Department.

May we have your comments regarding the installation of this generating set in view of Mr. Johnston's remarks that it might be possible to cooperate with the R.C.C.S. to supply electric power, as they have a generator in the immediate vicinity.

EVG/S.

Chief Engineer.
I wrote you on the 6th instant in regard to purchase of a 125 KVA A.C. Electric Generating set for Coppermine, N.W.T. I now wish to draw to your attention the necessity of smaller purchases at other places where such electric generators are necessary, but with more particular reference to the situation at Fort Good Hope, N.W.T.

At Fort Good Hope, Lots 13 and 14 have been chosen for the Non-Classroom Day School and Teachers' quarters. The building site is within possibly 100 yards of the buildings of the R.C.O.C.S., which are located southerly of the school site. At the Signals' Station it is necessary for maintenance men to be on duty 24 hours per day in connection with the power plant installed there. I understand it may be necessary soon to install additional units for the requirements of the R.C.O.C.Signals, but you can no doubt find this out from firsthand enquiry at their headquarters that they have definitely in mind.

The cost of an electric generator delivered and installed at Fort Good Hope will be about $8,000 and it will be necessary thereafter to have probably two men on duty throughout the winter season at least, in order to give 24 hours' attention to the operation of this unit. This appears an unnecessary expense, particularly when men are now on duty for just such a purpose. Would it be possible to request that R.C.O.C.Signals supply electric power for school purposes at Fort Good Hope? The economy in this over a period of years would be very considerable and well worthwhile.

Fort Good Hope is situated on a bluff, possibly 70 to 100 feet above the river level and the transportation of oil in drums from the waterfront presents a problem. Further, there are little trucking facilities at this point. I believe R.C.O.C.Signals plan to install a pipeline and tank so that fuel oil can be pumped directly from oil tender barge to the storage tank. With some sort of cooperation, a larger tank could be installed and a pipeline re-arranged from the river so that oil storage would be available for both the school and the several R.C.O.C.Signals' buildings.

It is also necessary to purchase A.C.electric generating sets at Fort Franklin and Arctic Red River. There are no Signals Stations at either place and it will be necessary to make this purchase in these two cases.

W.J. Johnston
District Engineer.

Deputy Minister,

Fort Good Hope Indian Day School.

The Department of Public Works will be constructing for this Department this summer a two-room Indian Day School with attached teachers' residence at Fort Good Hope, Northwest Territories. This building will be located on lots 13 and 14, approximately one hundred yards from the station of the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals. At this signal station, it is necessary for maintenance men to be on duty twenty-four hours per day in connection with the power plant installed there. I am advised that some consideration has been given to the installation of generating units for the requirements of the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals.

The District Engineer of the Department of Public Works has recommended that we approach you concerning the supplying of electrical power for school purposes at Fort Good Hope. The type of power unit required elsewhere for schools of this type is a Diesel engine capable of delivering approximately 18/20 horse power at 1200 R.P.M. The electrical generator is 12.5 K.V.A. 120/240 volt, 60 cycle alternating current unit.

The District Engineer of the Department of Public Works feels that it would be a waste of public funds to supply a generator to our school at this point when we are so close to a source of electrical power which might be shared by another Government Department. We are quite prepared to pay for this power if you can agree to authorizing its provision by the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals.

Your cooperation in this connection would be sincerely appreciated as we are doing everything possible to bring adequate educational facilities to the Indians, Whites, and Half-breeds of the Northwest Territories. The cost of building these schools is very high and any assistance which might be given by your Department would help greatly in the operation of this particular school at Fort Good Hope.

Dear Mr. Drury:

Fort Good Hope Indian Day School.

The Department of Public Works will be constructing for this Department this Summer a two-room Indian Day School with attached teachers' residence at Fort Good Hope, Northwest Territories.

This building will be located on lots 13 and 14, approximately one hundred yards from the station of the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals. At this signal station, it is necessary for maintenance men to be on duty twenty-four hours per day in connection with the power plant installed there. I am advised that some consideration is being given to the installation of additional generating units for the requirements of the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals.

The District Engineer of the Department of Public Works has recommended that we approach you concerning the supplying of electrical power for school purposes at Fort Good Hope. The type of power unit required elsewhere for schools of this type is a Diesel engine capable of delivering approximately 18/20 horse power at 1200 R.P.M. The electrical generator is 12.5 K.V.A., 120/240 volt, 60 cycle alternating current unit.

The District Engineer of the Department of Public Works feels that it would be a waste of public funds to supply a generator to our school at this point when we are so close to a source of electrical power which might be shared by another Government Department. We are
quite prepared to pay for this power if you can agree to authorizing its provision by the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals.

Your cooperation in this connection would be sincerely appreciated as we are doing everything possible to bring adequate educational facilities to the Indians, Whites, and Half-breeds of the Northwest Territories. The cost of building these schools is very high and any assistance which might be given by your Department would help greatly in the operation of this particular school at Fort Good Hope.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Minister.
May 9, 1949.

Colonel A. A. Anderson,
Acting Chief Engineer,
Department of Public Works,
Ottawa, Ontario.

In reply to your marginal notation of April 26th last, appearing on Major MacKay's memorandum of the 23rd ultimo in connection with the above, we comment as follows.

There is apparently a possibility that electrical power may be available for the above school through the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals who operate a generating station in this area. Should this be impossible the only other alternative would be to purchase and install an electric generating set to meet the requirements of the school.

Major Clark of the Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch discussed this matter with our Chief Architect on May 4th, and it was agreed that the Indian Affairs Branch would request the Public Works Department to contact the Department of National Defence and determine if they were in a position to supply power for the school.

Oil burning equipment is to be used in the forced hot air heating system provided for the school and any type of generating unit other than alternating current is not applicable to this type of heating equipment.

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

In reply to your letter of May 4th, it is regretted that the power you requested at Fort Good Hope, for the Indian Day School, cannot be supplied. The electrical power plant now running at Fort Good Hope is operating at full capacity. It is planned to install a larger power plant at this locality and it is hoped to have it installed about October, 1949, at which time the situation will be reviewed.

As you know, the Inter-Departmental Subcommittee (on Coordination of Construction) of the Advisory Committee on Northern Development has before it the subject of the supply of electrical power required by all Dominion Government Departments in the Northwest Territories. It is hoped that a satisfactory solution to the problem of power supply will be achieved at an early date.

Dear Sir:

As it is now at the close of water navigation on the Mackenzie River I am in a position to report regarding the school supplies which have been received at Fort Good Hope. As a result of a radiogram to the Carpenter Foreman of this Department at that place I received the following reply, dated September 24th:

"EFFECT SCHOOL TO BE READY FOR CLASSES BY DECEMBER FIRST ONE TEACH DESK, ABOUT 24 SCHOOL DESKS, GROCERY RATION, KITCHEN TABLE AND STOVE STORED AT SCHOOL. BOOKS, CLOTHING AT RCMP SO FAR HAVE NOT FOUND ANY OTHER FURNITURE FOR SCHOOL."

Evidently from the above, furniture for the classrooms has been received, as well as grocery rations and a kitchen table and stove, in addition to books and clothing. There appears to be a shortage of furniture to completely equip the living quarters in the manner which is probably required, on a permanent basis. However, this Department (Public Works) has beds, mattresses, kitchen equipment, etc., in connection with a camp which has been in operation for our construction crew. Thus, if your teacher arrives late this fall, there appears a chance of improvising from materials on hand so as to carry on over the coming winter.

The present indications are that the school will have reached such a stage of completion that classes can begin on December 1st or thereabouts. This is shortly after the end of the freeze-up period when our carpenter crew will have remained there over freeze-up, will be withdrawn from that place.

A general report regarding progress of construction of all schools is going forward to the Chief Engineer of the Public Works' Department and no doubt a copy will be transmitted to you.

Further work will be necessary in finishing the school next year. This has reference to completion of placing roofing on built-up terraces and level roof, which work it was not advisable to do during the cold weather of this fall; placing of outside siding which was deferred in order to advance interior work when sub-tradesmen of plumbers, heaters, and electricians were at the site; and other miscellaneous finish work.

Yours truly,

W.J. Johnston
DISTRICT ENGINEER.
Ottawa, Ont. Sept. 26, 1949.

Dear Sirs:

Re: Purchase Order 45506

We have just received your account for supplies forwarded to the teacher, Fort Good Hope Indian Day School, Fort Good Hope, N.W.T.

It is noted that there is an item of $18.38 on the account reading "Freight to Waterways". If you review the Purchase Order you will note that it was issued on the basis of "F.O.B. Waterways". Consequently, it will be necessary for us to deduct the $18.38 from the account.

There is also an item reading "Marine Insurance $5.60". As far as the Education Division is concerned, we do not appear to have paid such an item in the past. We would like to be advised why it is charged on this account.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, 18 October, 1949.

Superintendent of Education
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines and Resources.

For your information, I am attaching herewith copy of letter #2822 dated October 14th from District Engineer W. J. Johnston concerning the progress in construction of the school at Fort Good Hope, N.W.T. You will note Mr. Johnston anticipates that work for this season will be finished about December 1st and it would be advisable to have a caretaker and teacher dispatched to this location before the carpenter crew left there to maintain continuous heating in the building.

EVG/S.

R. Blais
Chief Engineer
In Letter No.2623 of September 30th I submitted a report on the progress of construction in various schools in the Northwest Territories.

In respect to Fort Good Hope, N.W.T., it was a little difficult at that time to advise definitely as to the stage of construction which might be reached on the school, as the existing weather conditions had a good deal to do with the situation. I am now advised that it would appear all work for this season on the school would be finished by December 1st. It would thus appear advisable for the Department of Education to arrange to have a janitor and teacher go north on the plane of Canadian Pacific Airlines leaving Edmonton Friday December 2nd. The teacher would thus be in a position to take over before our carpenter crew left there, and to maintain continuous heat in this building. It is not wise to close off the heat for a few weeks, if the present plans were that the teacher would arrive for opening of school on January 1st, 1950.

May this matter be drawn to the attention of Mr. R.F. Neary, Department of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

W.J. Johnston
DISTRICT ENGINEER.

R. Blais, Esq.,

We are advertising widely for a teacher at this school and hope to secure one by January 1, 1950.

Bernard F. Neary,

Re: Ft. Good Hope, Indian Day School.

On this date a copy of an Army message, forwarded to you by Mr. J.W. Mackinnon, School Inspector, has been sent to this office for my information by Mr. Mackinnon, having reference to the electrical power supply for the Ft. Good Hope Indian Day School.

I may state that in September 1949, I was aware that the Signals would be equipped to supply power to the Fort Good Hope Day School. At this time the local power unit had already been installed in the school, and the navigation season had ended insofar as obtaining a power line to be shipped to Good Hope for the purpose of installing a line from Signal power. Mr. W.J. Johnston, of the Department of Public Works, had known for some months previous to the installation of the local school plant that the R.C. Signals intended to install large power units for their own use and it was late September before I had it drawn to my attention that a separate power unit was to be installed in the Indian Day School.

It may be further stated that I made arrangements through Dr. Moore of Indian Health services to have a power line installed in the local Nursing station to be connected with the R.C. Signal power unit. Although Indian Health Services were contacted by Army message in September, full authority for installation of this power line, sanctioned by the Director of Signals, was not received at this office until December 6. I have not taken any action on this installation to date as I was intending to try and have the necessary materials shipped as far at Norman Wells N.W.T. by R.C.A.F.. The cost of shipping these materials by Canadian Pacific Airlines is exorbitant.

Mr. Mackinnon states that the
THAT THE caretaker as employed by me at the Good Hope school is incapable of maintaining the Power Unit. This man has been on pay since November 1st, 1949, and under the supervision of the R.C.A.F. and the local I.T.I. foreman, Mr. D.L. Hawkins. I have not received any word from either of these parties, that the man was incapable. At the time this Indian was hired, you will recall that it was our intention to have a teacher at Ft. Good Hope by January 1950, which would mean that only thirteen more days of service would be required from the Indian.

Although I concur with Mr. MacKinnon's idea, that power from the R.C. Signals would be a great asset at the School, I do not concur that the cost of operation under the present set-up would be greater than the cost of shipping wire for a new power line by C.I.Airline. I may further state that the power line to the Nursing Station, would have no connection with the power line to the school as the lines would run in entirely different directions.

The alternative, for the present set-up, would be to make arrangements through the R.C.A.F. at Edmonton, Alta and have the necessary materials forwarded as far as Norman Wells, N.W.T. by R.C.A.F. Aircraft. I intend on being in Edmonton, Alta., on December 22nd, and 23rd, and will approach Dr. Falconer of Indian Health Services with this proposal regarding the shipment of wire for the Nursing station.

L.E. Hunter,
Superintendent,
Fort Norman Indian Agency.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Electric Power for Fort Good Hope Indian Day School

Thanks for copy of your letter of January 26, 1950, to Mr. C. R. Anderson, Chief Architect's Branch, Department of Public Works, Ottawa. I would advise you to give the matter of the transfer of the power plant from Fort Good Hope to Arctic Red River considerable study before making any definite decision. It may be that I lack knowledge of just what is involved in this transfer. Wherever this plant is transferred, you should make sure that it will be used to light up the whole settlement. You might be reimbursed from the R.C.M.P. and any others who may connect to the line. It would be a very sound policy to give the R.C.M.P. free light on the understanding that their officer would attend to the plant. Members of the R.C.M.P. are usually mechanically inclined and would be able to attend to this matter.

Before the 16½ K.V.A. plants were purchased, I advocated the purchase of small 3,500 watt plants for our use. I wasn't invited to the meeting when it was agreed that the larger units would be purchased. Therefore, I did not have any say as to what type of equipment would be provided. However, we have the large plants -- so we must be realistic about the whole matter. It seems to me that it would be much better to move the plant to Fort McPherson and have it used to light up the school, nursing station, R.C.M.P., and any others wishing light. You might be able to make some kind of arrangement whereby the personnel of the nursing station or the R.C.M.P. would look after and maintain the plant for this service. This would remove your Department from the financial responsibility of maintenance and so forth. If the Arctic Red River school is to be made into an outpost school nursing station, it might be practical to move the two small plants from the nursing station at Fort Good Hope to Arctic Red River and use them for the school and nursing station. By having two small plants at Arctic Red River, there would be a stand-by at all times. Furthermore,
the R.C.S.S. at Fort Good Hope purchased two 25 K.V.A. plants on the understanding that the nursing station would connect to their power supply, so the nursing station will not require their two small plants.

Mr. Hall at Fort Norman is a well-qualified electrician. He informed me that the school at Fort Norman used 3,000 watts with everything turned on. I am inclined to the view that it would be much better to move the large plant to Fort McPherson for the use of the whole settlement and use the two small plants at Arctic Red River. I have discussed the above with Mr. Hall of Fort Norman who knows the local situation. He concurs in the above view and if it is possible to locate a small 2,500 or 3,000 watt plant to be installed along with the large unit, the situation would be clarified. The small plant could be used most of the time. It would operate at least 18 out of the 24 hours per day and result in a saving of at least $100 per month in fuel. It would pay for itself in a few months and result in a saving of a thousand dollars or more each year.

I am submitting the above suggestions for your consideration as I am vitally interested in the complete success of our schools and in economizing wherever possible.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.
February 10, 1950.

Mr. J.W. McKinnon,

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

Your suggestion with regard to the R.C.M.P. seems a sound one and I would suggest that you might discuss this matter with Mr. Hunter when you next see him. Having been in the R.C.M.P., no doubt a satisfactory arrangement can be worked out locally.

I have often wondered how the electrical plants and other equipment for these two-room Day schools in the Northwest Territories were decided. I certainly was not present at any meeting and I note that you were not there either. At the present time they are proving a source of great irritation to our Indian Superintendents and teachers. I wonder if we would not be better off without any type of lighting plant but just return to the old naptha lamp. The only one with which we have not had any difficulty is the unit at Fort Norman.

I would be very pleased if you would go into this whole matter with both Mr. Kirkby and Mr. Hunter and see whether a joint agreement cannot be reached with regard to the units at Fort Good Hope and Fort McPherson. These schools seem to have been designed on a rather complicated basis and therefore neither teachers nor other local...
inhabitants can handle the electrical equipment. If they give all this trouble when they are new, I shudder to think of the correspondence, Army Messenger, etc., which will flood into here when they are a few years older.

I am sending copies of this letter to both Mr. Kirkby and Mr. Hunter and I hope the three of you in the North can advise what should be done with regard to the electrical equipment and heating of the schools before work begins at Fort Franklin and Arctic Red River.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

On December 17, 1949, I stopped at Fort Good Hope long enough to inspect the new school building and would report as follows:

This building is in an unfinished state. I understand the Army plans to finish this project this summer. At present, one of the classrooms is on the way to completion; the other has much interior work to be done. The woodwork has not been finished or varnished. The floors are in a rough state. The walls are to be decorated and the outside of the building is to be sheeted.

I understand that this school has been connected with the local R.C.C.S. power supply. This is a good policy in view of the fact that there is no one available to attend to the local plant and that the local R.C.C. Station has an abundance of power for all local buildings.

It appears that this school is being well constructed and that we should have a very fine building when the interior and exterior work is completed, the plumbing connected to some outside set-up and the building finished in every detail.

A 2,000 gallon water tank, hot water heater, and shower room should be provided as has been provided at Fort Resolution. This is essential in the interests of good sanitation and health.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

Dear Sir:

I received your telegram of the 13th instant stating that you will try and have the teacher stay at Fort Norman, N.W.T., until the school is completed. You also mentioned it was not expedient to have the teacher remain at Fort Simpson, or at some other point temporarily until the teacher could be installed in the new school at Fort Good Hope. My reason for suggesting Fort Simpson was that there is property which I understand has been recently purchased for school purposes but I did not have full information as to what plans your Department might be making for supplying a teacher. In making that suggestion by radiogram I realise I was trespassing on a sphere of work which was not my own, but it was only done as a suggestion if it would relieve the problem of accommodation for several months until the Fort Good Hope school were fully completed.

In my radiogram I gave two dates of completion, namely October 15th and December 15th. The release of only fifty percent of the funds as supply has meant that we have had to hold back our construction activities so as to be assured the funds would not be exhausted before further money was granted. On this account a smaller crew was sent to Fort Good Hope than would otherwise have been the case, and the completion date of the building is thus set at December 15th. As mentioned in my radiogram, however, if it were possible to have the full grant for Fort Good Hope school made available immediately, further men could still be sent in so that the completion date could be advanced.

In regard to providing storage space for desks, janitor supplies, and food for the teacher, this will be attended to. I am sending instructions to Mr. D.J. Hawkins, our Foreman at Fort Good Hope, to take delivery of all these articles. Freight bills and the accounts for the purchase of the articles, will have to be attended to and I am asking him to send copies of the Bills of Lading as received by him, to me for forwarding to you. This should answer as your receipt so that the various accounts might be paid.

Since we hope to have the school at Fort Good Hope finished late this fall, the only method open was to send desks, janitor supplies, and food for the teacher. This would permit the building being occupied somewhere between October and December and classes in progress this winter.

In regard to the school at Fort Franklin, practically all our supplies are currently stored at Great Bear River where this Department has maintained a depot camp with a number of buildings situated there. The point on Great Bear River where the materials are stored is at St. Charles Rapids, where a portage road exists, said place of storage being about 40 miles west of Fort Franklin. It is intended to have all materials moved to Fort Franklin within the next several weeks, as it has not been possible to do so earlier on account of ice conditions in Great Bear Lake. A small carpenter crew is being placed at work at

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, File 909-5, part 1)
Fort Franklin to receive materials, erect temporary buildings, arrange for gravel and pour foundations, and do such other preliminary work as may be possible this year. Actual construction would thus be advanced next spring.

In regard to Fort Franklin, if the Purchase Requisition has not already been issued for desks, chairs and tables for the teacher, I would suggest this be not done. There are articles of this type on hand owned by this Department at Great Bear River which are surplus to our needs and they would probably answer your requirements. These could be declared surplus to War Assets and no doubt made available to you at a nominal charge.

Similarly, if you have not ordered desks, chairs and table for the teacher at Arctic Red River, would you please advise, as it is possible I might be able to release articles of this nature also to you, on the same basis as at Fort Franklin.

W.J. Johnston

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 3rd in reference to Arctic Red River and Fort Franklin, N.W.T., schools.

The subject matter of your letter and the enquiries contained therein have, in part, been covered in my letter No. 2622 of September 30th to the Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works, and regarding which I asked a copy be sent you.

Regarding Fort Franklin school, it was necessary to close down this work just prior to freeze-up so that our carpenters would not be caught there over freeze-up and run out of work. Owing to the lateness of the season it was impossible for workmen who should have installed the furnace and hot-air heating and also the electrical men, to arrive at this isolated point and complete their work without the danger of being caught over the freeze-up period. Since these sub-tradesmen could not carry out their part of the work, it was impossible for the carpenters to continue on the finish work within the building.

In regard to Arctic Red River, it was impossible to make a start on this building owing to the curtailment of funds at the first of the season in 1949. Providing funds of the full amount requested are available early in 1950 construction season, there appears a very good chance of completing the school at Arctic Red River in 1950.

In regard to school supplies, janitor supplies, desks, furniture for the living quarters, rations for the teachers, etc., for the schools, I am having enquiries made now as to what has been received in a general way at each location. It will not be possible to get a complete statement until mails are received after the freeze-up period, as this period is just now beginning in the North. At that time I shall advise you of such information as I have, and give up-to-date suggestions regarding dates of forwarding school supplies, and so forth, for 1950.

If you will refer to my letter No. 2622, you will note that a large proportion of the school supplies have been received at Coppermine, N.W.T. This is indeed very fortunate, since it will now be possible to begin school sessions once the building is completed. Great care and priority will, however, have to be given to the ordering of teachers' rations, and in this connection I would suggest at that time that one and one-half years' supply be ordered. According to records of the shipping; men there is an occasional year when no boats are able to get through the ice floes and reach Coppermine from Tuktoyaktuk. I do not want to be an alarmist about this, and it does not happen very often, but I have been reliably informed that this has happened.

Dear Sir:

I have been advised with regard to the difficulty in the present plumbing installations required for the two-room Indian day schools with attached teacherages, being constructed in the Northwest Territories.

Elsewhere we have been arranging for the installation of septic toilet combinations which require but a pail of water per bowl per day. There are two companies providing this equipment, some systems of which are particularly designed for school purposes. They are:

1. Rural Sewage Disposal Equipment, Limited,
   2067 Dundas St. W., Toronto, Ontario.

2. Caustic Sanitation, Limited,
   189 King Street, Dundas, Ontario.

Therefore, it will be in order to cancel the present plumbing contracts and to make the best possible terms with the plumbing tenderer. I would suggest that this matter be left for negotiating with the present Acting District Engineer at Edmonton.

The cost per seat of the septic toilets averages $175.00 per seat, which includes the bowl, pipe, septic tank, etc. In the case of the Fort Franklin School, a five-bowl unit would
be required with two bowls for the boys, two bowls for the girls and one bowl for the teacher. You will note that they are on thirty-six inch centres so that partitions can be erected between any combination of units. Consideration will have to be given to installing these units in a separate building because of the Permafrost conditions. Installation of these units in the present building might cause foundation settlement due to the heat generated.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Murray,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 20th with attached letter from the Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, concerning the plumbing installations at Fort Franklin Indian Day School.

The plumbing contractor - H.Kelly & Company - has been instructed to present his claim on the cancellation of the plumbing installation at the Fort Franklin school. No materials were delivered to the site at Fort Franklin but they are held in stores at Fort Smith. The Contractor has given no indication to date of what action he is taking towards the disposal of these fixtures but it is presumed that he is waiting for the results of a call for Tenders on plumbing installations in the buildings now under construction by this Department at Fort Smith and Hay River, and if H.Kelly & Company are successful in obtaining the work of this season, the surplus equipment can be utilized to their gain; otherwise they will have to dispose of it as best they can and may insist that the Department take these materials over.

The suggested septic toilets have been given some study by the Engineers of this office and from their knowledge of the terrain at Fort Franklin the opinion is that the Hygeosan Septic Toilet is not feasible for this location.

The Fort Franklin school is sited on a southern slope leading down to the lake. This slope is moss-covered and in the perma-frost area with very little over-burden above the solid rock. Reports from workmen who placed the piers under this building are that many of the piers are on solid rock, and the balance of them not far from rock. Under these circumstances it will be difficult to obtain cover for the septic tank under the toilet. The ground conditions are subjected to continual freezing and unless this steel tank was well insulated, it is very doubtful if the installation would work even in the summer time. The discharge from the septic tank is by continual overflow with no siphoning, and it is believed that with the low temperatures prevailing at Fort Franklin the pipe leading from the septic tank to the cesspit will soon ice up and the installation be inoperative.

In view of the above opinions it is felt that the installation as suggested is not feasible. This, however, is only the opinion formed by the Edmonton District Office and it is possible that the Indian Affairs Branch may have made installations in other northern areas, and if so, I ask that we be given more detail on the installation of this type of fixture and on what methods are taken to safeguard it from freezing. The folios and literature presented by the manufacturers give no assurance or indication that this equipment will operate under the conditions that will be experienced in the school installations not only at Fort Franklin, but also at Fort Norman, Arctic Red River, and other points in the Northwest Territories.

In view of the ground conditions prevailing in this area, my recommendation is that standard outside toilets be constructed by the Department of Public Works' construction crew this summer, as these are a necessity at all points, as it is the rule rather than the exception that inside toilet installations are inoperative a great deal of the time through uncontrollable factors, mainly weather.
No action will be taken by the District Office towards the installation of the septic toilet combinations until further advised by your office.

J.E. Kellett,
A/District Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Re: Fort Franklin Indian Day School

On June 28, 1950, I stopped for a short time at Fort Franklin and surveyed the local situation. There were about twenty Indian families at the post at the time of my visit. They live in log shacks and tents. There is great need of education at this point as sanitary conditions have much to be desired.

There were about twenty-five children of school age in the post at the time of my visit. The children appeared to be badly neglected.

Fort Franklin is, without a doubt, the most unattractive place in the Mackenzie District. The settlement borders on the western end of Great Bear Lake. It appears to have grown up without any plan or purpose. A long growth of vegetation covers the swampy ground. This is infested with mosquitoes and bull flies. At the time of my visit, the place was alive with flies and mosquitoes. Besides this, the air was filled with the smell of dogs as they are tethered in the settlement. The teacher engaged for Fort Franklin will require a sympathetic, helpful hand from Ottawa as his task will be an arduous one.

The school building has been built about 100 yards or more from the edge of Great Bear Lake. It is located in the swamp and mud. The building may sag and have out of shape this coming winter. As I took some pictures of this site, I shall send you some of them as soon as they have been developed. You will recall that W. J. Johnston, Chief Engineer, D. P. W., and I selected a good site close to the new Hudson's Bay Store; this site would have been ideal as it is on dry, high land. It was also fairly central for the children; whereas the present site is at the far end of the settlement. It will be necessary to level the grounds...
about the school, otherwise it will be impossible to use it for playground purposes.

The building is well under construction. It should be completed this summer. A well-qualified engineer should periodically check the work on this building in order to ensure good work.

The large 12 K.V.A. alternating current generator (similar to that installed at Fort Good Hope and Fort Resolution) will be a continual source of irritation if steps are not taken to prevent same. I have discussed the suitability of this type of generator with officers of the R.C.C.S., and others who are familiar with this type of equipment. They are not in favour of this type of lighting plant as it is too large for our needs. These generators are quite large and beyond the stage where a handyman can care for them; they require the care of an expert. As Fort Franklin is isolated from the rest of the world for many months of the year, a small 1000 Watt emergency A.C. generator should be provided or else a D.C. generator should replace the A.C. plant which I understand is now on site. You will realize that it is necessary to operate an alternating current plant twenty-four hours a day in order to keep the electric furnace operating; whereas a direct current plant will require eight or ten hours of operation per week. With a direct current plant, I believe the savings in fuel alone would amount to well over $100.00 per month.

Respectfully submitted,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

This letter was forwarded to me by Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Superintendent of Schools of the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs.

We have included in our estimates a sum for the construction of an Indian day school at Rocher River. Rocher River.

42 Indian families, totalling 96 Indians live at Rocher River. The Half-Breed and white people increase the population to 140. Approximately 25 miles up the Talton River is another settlement - Rat River, where a few Indians and white trappers live. For the purpose of this report Rocher River and Rat River are considered as one settlement.

Rocher River is an ideal location for an Indian Village. Fishing is good and caribou are available during the open season. Fur is by no means plentiful but there is enough, including the spring rat hunt, to afford a living to an Indian who will try to support his family.

In spite of the above, and even though the Indians are Chipewyans of the same band as those at Fort Resolution and Snowdrift, Rocher River is the dirtiest and most poverty-stricken settlement in the agency. I flew into Rocher River early last June and the stench of garbage and rotting caribou hides tossed out of the front doors and along the river bank where the dogs are tied the uncleanness of the homes and the general filth of the settlement were a revelation. The place was cleaned up somewhat when I threatened prosecution under the Public Health Ordinance but probably will be just as dirty this spring.

The people at Rocher River make very little effort to support themselves and none at all to improve their conditions. During a recent visit I found caribou drying in only one house, that of the Chief, Pierre Frise. The usual routine is to sleep all morning then to loaf and play cards for the remainder of the day and all night.

These people are almost completely demoralized. I recently treated a 14 year old girl for V.D.C. and found her to be four months pregnant. Three white trappers, brothers, of Rate River have been fathers of illegitimate babies by Treaty Indian women, the youngest brother becoming a father in January of this year. Several girls have had more than one illegitimate child and several Treaty Indian women, some of them married, are living with Half-breeds in common-law status.
The only reason I can see for the situation at Rocher River is the influence of the white people who live in that settlement. Mr. E.R. DeMelt, a free trader and his common-law wife, Mrs. Rose Metcalfe, came to Rocher River approximately ten years ago. They run a small store and a small sawmill. In addition, Mr. DeMelt has a trapping license.

The Rocher River Indians require help, not financial assistance but mental stimulation. The natural resources could very easily sustain the population. There is no place within a hundred miles of Rocher River and Rat River which is as suitable for people living in the Indian fashion.
July 16, 1948.

Extract from report from Mr. Johnston, District Engineer dated October 15th on the Rocher River Day School.

RE: ROCHER RIVER.

The 2 Classroom Day School and Teachers' Quarters has been erected and has outside finish on the walls and a built-up tar and gravel roof recently completed by a roofing contractor from Edmonton. The roughing-in has been done for electricity. The hot-air furnace and heating ducts are now being installed. It was not possible for the plumbing contractor to deliver materials to destination this year, owing, in part to the lateness in which the contract was let, and also to the fact that there are only about four boats per season from Fort Smith to this point. Carpenter work has advanced to a point where three carpenters could finish by early December. Work on this project was closed down for the season on the 16th instant, largely due to the impossibility of having a generator delivered which was necessary for operation of the blower in connection with the hot-air furnace. I wrote you by letter # 2961 on October 6th, in reference to specifications calling for a fully automatic electric generating machine and the reluctance of firms to supply this unit. I am still awaiting your instructions if a manually controlled machine could be installed.

So far as I know, no desks or classroom fittings have been received at Rocher River, and there is no furniture on hand for the teachers' quarters. In fact the arrival of these fittings, furniture and so forth, at a settlement where there is little, if any, warehouse storage space, presents a problem and it is doubtful if such should be delivered until the school building is ready to receive these articles, which represent a considerable investment. It should, however, be possible to begin work next spring on the school project and have it completed early in June when the first boat arrives there. Incoming shipments of furniture, classroom supplies, fittings, rations for the teacher and so forth should be scheduled to arrive on the first boat arriving at Rocher River next year. That would permit the opening of school by July 1st if this were desired.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of May 26th, in connection with my transfer, I wish to state that I accept Rock River, there being no other choice.

I would not consider staying on here, even if there were three teachers to help me, simply because I don't enjoy living among narrow-minded people such as are some of the local Protestants who were opposed to my taking charge of the school on the grounds that I am Catholic.

From a financial angle, however, I would be tempted to consider being hired as janitor for the school, as the janitor's monthly salary is $25.00; which is $3.00 more than the teacher's salary; and I doubt if he works an average of four hours per day.

Yours very truly,

Harley Bellavance

Dear Mr. Blackburn:

While I have been writing to you about Fort Good Hope, I have always kept in mind your original interest in the Rocher River School. During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the school term I believe it worth while to report on my observations at each point.

On September 14th proceeded to Roche River with Agency boat. This school had opened for the first time on September the 6th, and was progressing very favourably. The day I attended this school 35 pupils were in attendance and a few more were expected to come in. Not too much past this number or possibly a few more will be the limit. Some of these children will move out with their parents for the winter hunt but I believe well over 25 will be in attendance at all times.

The Superintendent of Indian Education was contacted and permission to construct a limited number of tables and benches to accommodate the extra pupils was obtained. These tables were to be so constructed that they can be used as ping-pong tables in a games room once more desks are obtained.

A large number, if not all the natives at this settlement are in the settlement for the greater part of the summer and now that we have a welfare teacher at this point, I believe we should encourage gardening, etc., if we are to improve the welfare of these natives. Mr. & Mrs. Blackburn are very enthusiastic about doing just this work and as we have a tractor at Resolution, I will have it taken to Roche River and plow up a section of the school yard as well as an area for communal gardens. It is my understanding that this type of work is part of the Welfare teachers job and in this country the first requirement is to improve the Indians standard of living by better methods of obtaining his food and clothing. A request for rakes and hoes for the spring gardening was noted and is on attached requisition.

As to Mr. Blackburn's status, it is obvious that he expects
to be second teacher when there are over 30 pupils and wants to hire a man to haul water, carry in wood and do the janitor jobs. I understood that Mr. Blackburn was to look after the school and we were not going to hire a janitor. From my talks with him I gathered that he felt that the teaching of the extra pupils and the night classes he took made it impossible to do the janitor work. As Mrs. Blackburn is the welfare teacher, I thought it was her place to teach the older persons and to contact the Indians in the settlement.

Both these people seem enthusiastic and should, I hope, help to make Bowser River a better place for the Indians. I would at the same time like to know whether we are to hire the services of an extra man as janitor. I cannot see how two teachers on full time pay are needed to teach 50 pupils, but can be corrected.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last year and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

(Sgd.) I.E.Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies,

Dear Sir:

I inspected the Rocher River Indian Day School on Tuesday, November 29th and would report as follows:

There were 37 pupils in attendance at the school and I was under the impression that the children were learning considerable under Mrs. Blackburn's supervision. Complete report of this school will follow as soon as time permits.

During my visit to this settlement, the local people requested that I attend a public meeting in the school. At this meeting, Mr. Duncan was elected unanimously, by all present, as a school trustee. He said that he would be willing to act as custodian of school property and do everything possible to further education. All of the parents in this district are Roman Catholic, yet they were very disappointed that religious education was given at the school. They told me that they had informed the local priest that they would withdraw their children from the school if he continued to enforce their children to remain during the religious education period. The priest told them that they would be excommunicated from the church, to which they replied that this made little difference to them. He further informed them that he would cut their Family Allowance payments if they did not remain for religious education.

The local people also acquainted me with the fact that the Blackburns had announced that they would like to have the local priest live in the school residence while at this point. The local people greatly resented any interference in the school by the local priest and informed me that they would withdraw their children from the school if a satisfactory solution was not arrived at immediately.

In order to keep this school operating, the parents so desiring demanded that they have the right to submit a written statement to the Principal requesting that their children be exempt from the religious education period from 3:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. Mrs. Blackburn indicated that this plan would work quite well.

I am submitting this statement in order that you will be informed of the developments in this
area. I would advise that this matter be left entirely in the hands of the local people at Rocher River and I am confident that this is the only possible means of arriving at a satisfactory settlement as far as the local residents are concerned.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR,

LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

SCHOOL BOARDS - INDIAN SCHOOLS,
NORTHWEST TERRITORIES.

We have noted with some concern Mr. McKinnon's action in apparently forming School Committees or School Boards in the Northwest Territories. As you are aware, the Indian Act does not provide for the establishment of these School Boards nor has it been felt necessary to establish these in view of the fact that the entire cost of Indian education is borne by the Government.

Our Indian Superintendent has written at some length concerning the Roche River School and I felt you would be interested in his comments regarding Mr. McKinnon's action:

"At Roche River we have two factions, one the Hudson's Bay trader and the other a free trader. In between there is a group of no good white trash who are dead beats anywhere. To establish a school board of this type of person or in a community such as this will only give the teacher untold grief. None of the whites are out of the funding, which it is in no uncertain terms and the Bay Manager is just as much a part of the whole thing as any one else. Even the Police dislike going to Roche River because all one hears is a long series of fantastic tales about one party when he visits one store and then hears equally as fantastic from the other store when he visits it. To make the teacher responsible to any of these individuals would be to drive him out by the first plane."
"The above probably does not interest you but it is one of my objections to having a trustee out of the Roche River whites appointed. If these people were a little more interested in the school and incidentally the Indians than they are about their own fairy tales, which do cause plenty of trouble then I would be in favor of a trustee but not the way things stand. A trustee from any section of the Roche River whites would be a stool pigeon who would haunt the teacher day and night.

"I feel the school work is progressing very favorably and the Indians seem only too willing to attend. There is no trouble with them and all social activities are very orderly and very well attended by these people. The only ones who do not seem to know their places are some of the whites who as in most places have been the real offenders where it comes to bringing alcohol to the Indians. I think this is answering a long felt need in Roche River and if the Teacher can be kept out of the petty jealousy that exists then we need not worry about the final outcome being a success."

RATIONS - INDIAN DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS

At some of the settlements in the Northwest Territories the assortment of groceries and provisions available for purchase is rather limited. In many cases, the stocks are meagre and there is little variety in the items offered.

To overcome this situation and as a measure of assistance to the teachers, arrangements have been made with the Hudson's Bay Company to have requisitions for rations filled at Edmonton and shipped directly to the individual teacher.

The Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare has prepared a ration list of the items required for one person living for one year in the North. We have secured approximate prices as quoted by the Hudson's Bay Company in Edmonton. Attached is this list, with the prices, of course, being subject to variation.

On the basis of this list the teacher may then prepare an order and forward same to this office. We will then place the order with a wholesale grocery firm in Edmonton and the items will be shipped by water transportation. The cost at wholesale price of the rations purchased in this manner on behalf of the teacher, together with transportation charges on same, will be deducted on a monthly basis from the living allowance paid to northern employees of the Department. The maximum that can be deducted from the Northern Living Allowance is $35. a month (i.e.) $350. for Day School Teachers and $420. from Welfare Teachers.

In cases where the cost of the rations and transportation charges is in excess of the above possible deductions, the teacher will be obliged to pay the difference.

The requisition showing the requirements must reach Ottawa prior to March 15, 1950, complete with express address and shipping instructions to ensure delivery during the navigation season.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Mr. Neary:

When we arrived in Rocher River last September, there was no food or ration which we expected to be in already. We placed an order with the Hudson's Bay Co. for the amount of $640.00.

May I ask you to pay that amount to the Hudson's Bay Co. at Edmonton and take out a monthly payment out of my salary and allowance starting from February until August inclusively.

The situation should be different next year since we shall be right in Rocher River and in a position to order whatever we really need with what will be left from this year's mess.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Co. in Edmonton.

Hoping that my request meets your approval,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Mrs. Annette Blackburn.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary:

This is to inform you that Mr. Blackburn has not received any salary yet for his teaching or any other work he has been doing since the first of September.

He has been teaching the Junior classroom with beginners from 6 to 15 years of age. Adult Education takes all his nights. You must have received a report on that subject from Mr. McKinnon, Superintendent of Education at Yellowknife, who suggested on his visit in the last days of November that Mr. Blackburn should receive a monthly salary of around $160.00 for the work he has been doing. The plant and the janitor work take most of his free hours. The school, unfinished as it is, requires continuous heating day and night and I do not exaggerate. He has to be up every hour and a half to keep the fires going to keep the rooms not warm but only cool. We have to go in the furnace room to warm up during school hours.
Mr. Kirkby, who came yesterday, was surprised to hear that Mr. Blackburn had received nothing yet.

I do merely hope that Mr. Blackburn's position will be cleared up in the near future.

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Mrs. Annette Blackburn,
Rochor River, N.W.T.
Dear Sir:

School maintenance and the maintenance of the light plant and engine at Rocher River school have been one continual source of worry from the time this school was taken over. I am enclosing a copy of each wire received from Mr. Blackburn at Rocher River and also the reply on the action taken. From these wires it will be seen that Blackburn knows nothing whatsoever about equipment and he has made himself so highly disliked by his attitude and actions that no one will give him any assistance when it comes to looking after the plant.

A complete instruction book; both for the engine and the battery bank; is left on the tool bench beside the engine and as the Lister is simplest engine to handle anyone with the ambition to read the instructions should be able to handle the plant. The changing of a fuse seemed to me to be lack of the very simplest of common sense rules.

On my last trip into Rocher River I received a wire that the plant had played out and that it was impossible to start it. I took in the Dept. of Transport mechanic from Resolution and Blackburn was sure that the lad who ran the plant last fall had purposely damaged it. On examination it was found that the fuel tank had run dry and the engine stonked so that when the tank was again filled an air lock was caused and the plant would not start. Blackburn had been filling the engine with the radiator half full and when the plant would not start had started to pull things off and had drained oil over everything. It was after seeing this mess that I requested the fire extinguishers and ordered the plant cleaned up. I consider this man will ruin the plant in very short order and he has only made the settlement of Rocher River into a more disorganized place than it ever was before.

I believe that Mrs Blackburn may be a good teacher but Mr. Blackburn thinks he is boss and is ruining all the good she is doing. The first requirement at Rocher River is to run a good school and make it a credit before moving out to try and run the Indians and whites, when he cannot run the establishment he is in without wrecking it when ever our back is turned.

This school has a light plant and the furnace is dependant on power for circulation. If we do not have a teacher or teacher's husband who can run these two simple units we will not be able to install our water system and other equipment for fear of it freezing up for lack of care or knowledge of the simplest equipment. I have done all I can to help keep these schools on the go and to make life pleasant for the teacher but when a man is receiving pay to do a job it should either be done right or the man must be replaced.

The number of pupils in attendance at this school is from 30 to 35 and it is very doubtful if it will be higher.
in the near future, in fact it is much more likely to decline with the moving of families of T.B. patients to Residential school.

I am very anxious to see these school establishments operate smoothly and that we should get the most out of them for the money spent. If the physical plant itself cannot be looked after by the man we now have the only solution is to get rid of him and put in someone who will show a little initiative and common sense which must be done if we are not going to ruin the whole equipment now installed.

The following wires have been exchanged and results are as indicated.

Wire: Electric plant needs to be serviced by experienced repair man stop One battery connection burned with a flash when starting motor afraid # batteries will discharge not using motor until checked, signed Blackburn.

Answer: Please explain fully where flash occurred as I wish to take in repairs first trip, signed Kirkby.

Wire: Flash occurred at battery post and almost burned one post off battery stop Post still holds but badly damaged would suggest one new battery, signed Blackburn.

Wire: Motor running good but no registration of charge on panel stop waiting George to return this week and check and will wire results. Signed Blackburn.

Answer: Did you check reverse current relay to see if it is making contact when engine running at full speed stop Check points and hold in with insulated screw driver in not making contact stop also check fuses. Signed Kirkby.

Wire: George McCallum checked plant yesterday and found defective fuse on switchboard stop plant running satisfactorily, signed Blackburn.

Wire: Oil pressure gauge shows no pressure on plant engine stop do you wish McCallum to check. Signed Blackburn.

Answer: Have service man clean oil lines, filters and screens also check pump to restore pressure, signed Kirkby.

Wire: Plant stopped operating at two forty pm today suggest expert checkup stop done everything I know, Blackburn.

Flew into Rocher River with one mechanic and found plant in filthy condition, plant had been let run dry of fuel oil and air lock had formed. Instruction book on table and if this had been read by Blackburn he could have fixed it.

Wire: No registration of voltage on panel stop motor runs good but no oil pressure indicated have closed school as too cold for operation, signed Blackburn.

Answer: Local engineer advises engine must not be run without oil pressure. Signed E.C. Devlin, Clerk.

On my return I wired you at Ottawa for permission to take in engineer and electrician to check equipment. This series of wires are the work of a man who has no knowledge of equipment at all and as we are not able to have an electrician make a trip into Rocher River every time a fuse blows or a mechanic every time the man forgets to put oil or fuel into the plant I believe that it is time to remove him from the job otherwise we will ruin the whole plant and still in the end have to get a new man in to operate the equipment.
I do not feel that Mr. Blackburn has made any attempt to make the school equipment run and even though this school is of very poor construction I am sure that the equipment can be run in a much better way. It is not possible to hire the local Indians so to this work as none of them have any ideas regarding mechanical equipment, although it would be impossible to do less than is done now. This school is situated in a very small settlement and it would not be possible to have both a teacher and a janitor, but if the teacher was to have some knowledge of mechanical equipment and give him authority to hire local help to wash floors, polish and wax, carry wood, bring in ice, clean up the engine room, keep fuel in the engine and so forth then we should not have the present grief we do have. All the extra jobs should be done on an hourly wage basis and the teacher given an extra $30.00 per month to check the light plant himself. It is impossible to hire anyone with mechanical knowledge in Roche River and no man will look after the light plant for $30.00 if this is all he has to do.

I believe that the janitor work and the light plant and wood and ice hauls should be a full time job and whether the principal has to hire it done or whether we put in a married woman and her husband to do the work we are going to be forced to pay out at least $150.00 per month for the work done. Mr. Blackburn has only received the $30.00 per month that I have mentioned through to him and he felt that he was to receive a stated amount whether teaching or not and that when he was teaching he would not attend to the plant but would turn over the $30.00 to someone else to do the work. I have a copy of your letter of August 15th, file 910-1 (E) and I must admit that it is slightly misleading if not carefully examined and as Mr. Blackburn is too excitable to concentrate he took your letter to mean that he would receive a salary whether teaching or not and when not teaching an extra $30.00 to look after the plant, also that when he did start to teach he would pass the $30.00 on to someone else. This is his complaint about salary but everything has gone haywire from the day he arrived and he needs daily supervision regarding the equipment. I cannot give this as it costs $150.00 for every plane ride into the place therefore I find that I have to agree with Mr. McKinnon that we need a local school board or sub-trustee or a home and school association that will take the well being of the school serious and check up on teacher and janitors who donot perform their required duties.

In the Northwest Territories we have to rely upon each man to run his or her own establishment without daily supervision and unless we receive this type of person everything will go downhill. A service man cannot be on call every hour of the day to out-of-the-way places, and as they are large establishments with much technical equipment, then we must have teachers who know the rudiments of electricity and mechanics or we will never keep our schools open. At many settlements schools are hooked up to the Army Signals or Dept. of Transport and at such a place maintenance amounts to sweeping and oiling one motor. At my two large schools we have self contained units that rely on their own plants and equipment and we must have teachers or teachers husbands who can qualify enough to do the very simplest of mechanical chores such as changing fuses, keeping plant and motors oiled and fuel in the tank.

I know these schools are set in isolated settlements and that teachers are hard to get, but from the very location of these schools it is a must that we get couples who can be relied upon to run the place on their own in order that we may receive the full benefit of the moneys spent.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

I.F. Kirkby
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Neary:

You will find enclosed a copy of a letter which I have just sent to Mr. Kirkby, also a cheque of $90.00 covering the plant maintenance and janitor allowance for October and November.

May I ask you to permit me a few complaints or remarks as to what that cheque implies. Firstly we feel that we are being abused by having to pay the janitor expenses for the three months ending October 31 because Mr. Kirkby told us that it should come out of the $40.00 monthly allowance for that purpose. We spent less than that doing a lot of the work ourselves. Our intentions on that subject are exposed in my letter to Mr. Kirkby. In that same letter you will note the statement made on the plant maintenance. I wish to state here that Mr. Johnstone, of Edmonton, made a special note of the plant stating it had not given satisfaction even being put to use for its purpose. It is in need of repair or expert checkup because nobody seems to know the trouble.
Mr. Kirkby was surprised to hear my statement, two weeks ago, that I had to run the plant from 8 to 15 hours every day. Mr. Kirkby thought that a two day operation every week was sufficient.

Teaching: We have over 35 children registered and the ages of the children of the lower grades, mainly grades 1 & II, vary from 7 to 15. Some of them will make two grades this first year. 6 Beginners are doing a very strong Grade 1 already.

Night School: Mr. McKinnon, Superintendent of Education, has witnessed, through a meeting of the Indians, of the work accomplished in that sphere. The results obtained are similar to the ones in the day school.

The Indians have been organized, by a committee of Indians, and they manage the expenses of the Xmas tree and dances held every other week. Plans have been made for next year's Xmas tree. Games have been bought and the school is the real Community centre as it was expected. All that has not prevented them to go trapping or hunting as proved by a weekly checkup.

I figure that the salary mentioned by Mr. McKinnon is fair with all the work and responsibility it calls for. It is with reluctance that I return the enclosed cheque hoping that everything will be duly adjusted.

Yours truly,

It was understood, before we left for Rocher River, that the allowance of $30.00 was for the plant maintenance. Nothing was mentioned of any janitor work. I am not satisfied with the treatment I am receiving for all the work done. I am returning the $90.00 cheque to Mr. Neary with a letter stating the situation of Rocher River. I am enclosing a copy of said letter. In the meantime, I wish to let you know that I cannot work from 5 in the morning till 11 at night, and get up every 90 minutes to try to keep the building warm or as close to it as possible.
This continuous upkeep of the fires is absolutely necessary to keep the school opened all day. Afternoon sessions would be the only alternative.

Nothing has been received for the teaching done although close to 40 children are registered.

Adult education seems to be of no value although results obtained vouch for the work done.

Should there be no adjustment before the first of February, I regret to ask you to appoint someone to look after the plant and the janitor work. Speaking of janitor work, you told us that the sum of $40.00 per month was allowed and we went on that basis. We are not to be held responsible for the amount spent for that purpose until the end of October and shall not pay same. The sum of $60.00 was paid to Mr. G. McCullum for the upkeep of the plant for the time I was away. I wonder who should refund that amount.

I sincerely hope that the matters mentioned in this letter will receive your attention and I would greatly appreciate your decision at your earliest convenience.

I remain,

Yours truly,
