Extract from Annual Report on Rocher River of the Fort Resolution Northwest Territories Agency, dated 1947-48.

Rocher River.

42 Indian families, totalling 96 Indians live at Rocher River. The Half-Breed and white people increase the population to 140. Approximately 25 miles up the Talton River is another settlement - Rat River, where a few Indians and white trappers live. For the purpose of this report Rocher River and Rat River are considered as one settlement.

Rocher River is an ideal location for an Indian Village. Fishing is good and caribou are available during the open season. Fur is by no means plentiful but there is enough, including the spring rat hunt, to afford a living to an Indian who will try to support his family.

In spite of the above, and even though the Indians are Chipewyans of the same band as those at Fort Resolution and Snoudrift, Rocher River is the dirtiest and most poverty-stricken settlement in the agency. I flew into Rocher River early last June and the stench of garbage and rotting caribou hides tossed out of the front doors and along the river bank where the dogs are tied the uncleanness of the homes and the general filth of the settlement were a revelation. The place was cleaned up somewhat when I threatened prosecution under the Public Health Ordinance but probably will be just as dirty this spring.

The people at Rocher River make very little effort to support themselves and none at all to improve their conditions. During a recent visit I found caribou drying in only one house, that of the Chief, Pierre Frise. The usual routine is to sleep all morning then to loaf and play cards for the remainder of the day and all night.

These people are almost completely demoralized. I recently treated a 14 year old girl for V.D.G. and found her to be four months pregnant. Three white trappers, brothers, of Rate River have been fathers of illegitimate babies by Treaty Indian women, the youngest brother becoming a father in January of this year. Several girls have had more than one illegitimate child and several Treaty Indian women, some of them married, are living with Half-breeds in common-law status.
The only reason I can see for the situation at Rocher River is the influence of the white people who live in that settlement. Mr. E.R. DeMelt, a free trader and his common-law wife, Mrs. Rose Metcalfe, came to Rocher River approximately ten years ago. They run a small store and a small sawmill. In addition, Mr. DeMelt has a trapping license.

The Rocher River Indians require help, not financial assistance but mental stimulation. The natural resources could very easily sustain the population. There is no place within a hundred miles of Rocher River and Rat River which is as suitable for people living in the Indian fashion.

For the purpose of this report Rocher River and Rat River are considered as one settlement.

Rocher River is an ideal location for an Indian Village. Fishing is good and caribou are available during the open season. Fur is by no means plentiful but there is enough, including the spring rat hunt, to afford a living to an Indian who will try to support his family.

In spite of the above, and even though the Indians are Chipewyans of the same band as those at Fort Resolution and Snowdrift, Rocher River is the dirtiest and most poverty-stricken settlement in the agency. I flew into Rocher River early last June and the stench of garbage and rotting caribou hides tossed out of the front doors and along the river bank where the dogs are tied the uncleanness of the homes and the general filth of the settlement were a revelation. The place was cleaned up somewhat when I threatened prosecution under the Public Health Ordinance but probably will be just as dirty this spring.

The people at Rocher River make very little effort to support themselves and none at all to improve their conditions. During a recent visit I found caribou drying in only one house, that of the Chief, Pierre Frise. The usual routine is to sleep all morning then to loaf and play cards for the remainder of the day and all night.

These people are almost completely demoralized. I recently treated a 14 year old girl for V.D., and found her to be four months pregnant. Three white trappers, brothers, of Rat River have been fathers of illegitimate babies by Treaty Indian women, the youngest brother becoming a father in January of this year. Several girls have had more than one illegitimate child and several Treaty Indian women, some of them married, are living with Half-breeds in common-law status.
The only reason I can see for the situation at Roche River is the influence of the white people who live in that settlement. Mr. E.R. DeMelt, a free trader and his common-law wife, Mrs. Rose Metcalfe, came to Roche River approximately ten years ago. They run a small store and a small sawmill. In addition, Mr. DeMelt has a trapping license.

The Roche River Indians require help, not financial assistance but mental stimulation. The natural resources could very easily sustain the population. There is no place within a hundred miles of Roche River and Rat River which is as suitable for people living in the Indian fashion.

I am attaching hereto for your information and advice copy of letter, dated October 6th, from District Engineer Johnston concerning the school building at Rocher River, N.W.T.

You will particularly note Mr. Johnston's statements concerning the electric generating unit and advise me in the matter. You will also note that apparently there will be no possibility of this school being used during the present winter since no furniture has arrived and the suggestion that work on the building be suspended until next spring when the work which is practicable to do this year is completed. Will you please let me have your comments on this.

K. Bleis,
Chief Engineer.

Encl.
work has been in progress on the two-classroom day school and teacher's quarters at Roche River during the present summer, and a stage of construction reached whereby the building is erected, built-up roofing placed, chimney installed and the finishing work well advanced. The hot-air heating system has also been installed. There remains incomplete the following:

(a) Water supply
(b) Plumbing
(c) Electric lighting generating plant

Regarding (a), water supply, an effort was made during the past summer, using native labour, and without obtaining an oil-digging outfit, to sink a well by hand in the hope of obtaining water. If water could have been obtained in the vicinity of the building, it would have been an advantage to the project; however, when water was not obtained at a reasonable depth, it was considered too much expense would be incurred to continue. However, the effort was abandoned. Incidentally, the well area was enlarged so as to provide storage space for vegetables, so as to obtain some benefit from the expenditure made.

It is now proposed to pipe water from the Nelson River by a water pipe contained in an insulated box carried on top of the ground. The pump and piping for this, however, will have to await delivery after opening of navigation next year. The pump itself has been purchased.

With reference to (b), Plumbing, H. Kelly & Company have delivered the materials at Fort Smith this fall and will deliver to destination and make the necessary installation next year.

Regarding (c), Electric generating unit, there is attached copy of specification received from Engineering and Construction Division of the Department of Mines and Resources. When this specification was submitted to electric supply firms in this city, the response was very disappointing - three firms replying "unable to quote", and Canadian Railroads-Morse Limited submitting a quotation practically under protest. The gist of the objection was the phrase in the specification: "Will run on small automatic start when a load of 100 watts is demanded, and shall continue in operation until full load drops below this value, at which time it shall automatically stop." The local manager of Canadian Railroads-Morse called at this office and stated that, although his firm could supply a unit fulfilling completely the specifications demanded, they were very reluctant about doing so. It was claimed that the electrical part of the generator in a fully automatic machine could, very easily, go out of commission, and should have a fully-qualified electrical man available to make repairs. If their machine were shipped to isolated points such as in the Northwest Territories, there would be no qualified electrician (and it took a particularly good one for this repair work); and their equipment would get a bad name through poor service. Likewise, this Department would be without electricity, possibly at a very critical time during the winter season with short days and the need for electric lighting. Another objection to the fully-automatic machine, from the manufacturer's point of view, is that there would be a tendency for people to neglect the generator.

(OVER)
itself, not use gas and oil when required, with the result that the engine would run dry. In view of these circumstances, the manufacturers strongly recommend cancellation of the automatic feature, and supplying a machine which is manually controlled. The price of such a manually-controlled machine is $3,538.00, f.o.b. Waterways, Alberta.

The generator, which had to be imported from the United States, would require an Import Permit; also, it was so late in the season before the situation was fully realized, that delivery could not be made by water transportation in 1948.

May I have your instructions, please, if the specifications for the generator may be amended by deleting the fully-automatic features. An order will then be placed for the supply of such a machine, to be delivered during the present fiscal year to either Edmonton or Waterways, so that it can go forward at opening of navigation early in 1949.

In a late radiogram received from Kocher River, I learn that no furniture for the classrooms, nor other necessities, have been received at Kocher River. This would presumably mean that no furniture has arrived for the teacher's quarters. Under these circumstances, I would suggest that construction proceed as far as it is practicable to do so this year without incurring unnecessary expense, and that the work be suspended until next spring. At that time, the small amount of carpenter work remaining to be done can be attended to and arrangements for the delivery of classroom furniture and supplies for the teacher's quarters. By this means, the school would probably be completed soon after the arrival of the first boat and, if the furnishings were received at the same time, classes could begin about July 15th. It is considered this information should be passed to Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Inspector of Schools for the Northwest Territories, and a spare copy of this letter is enclosed for this purpose.

May I have your instructions in the above matter, please.

(Sgd) W. J. Johnston

Provide crated, ready for freight shipment the following:

1 only fully automatic diesel electric lighting plant. The engine shall be diesel compression-ignition type, capable of delivering approximately 15 H.P., at 1200 R.P.M. when burning No.1 or 2 light fuel oil. The engine shall be water cooled using pump and radiator with other type fan. The engine shall be direct connected through a semi-flexible coupling to, and mounted on the same base as, a 7k K.V.A., 120/240 volts 60 cycle single phase alternating current generator with exciter automatically controlled to give 2% regulation and mounted at end of generator shaft. Provide electric starting motor battery and automatically regulated battery charger. (The plant shall automatically start when a load of 50 watts is demanded and shall continue in operation until the load drops below this value, at which time it shall automatically stop). Provide control panel containing all automatic controls and also push button station for manual control. Provide voltmeter, ammeter frequency meter and manual reset circuit breaker. Supply automatic shutdown for low lube oil pressure, high water temperature and continual cranking on failure of engine to start on load demand. Provide 300 gallon oil storage tank for mounting outside of building on supports as directed and furnish 50 feet of 3/4" copper (type K) pipe for oil suction line between tank and diesel engine. Provide 3/4" bossed tapping on steel pipe nipple and brass fitting coupling for connection between 3/4" galvanized steel nipple and 3/4" streamline copper fuel line to diesel engine. Provide fittings necessary at engine fuel intake to take 5/4" fuel line.

Generator unit shall be equipped with radio interference suppressors. Generating equipment supplied shall be new and shall be fully guaranteed and shall be complete with exhaust pipe (10 foot) muffler, foundation bolts, all required wiring between generating unit and control panel and all appurtenances necessary for a complete installation ready for operation.

Detailed instructions shall be supplied for the installation, operation and maintenance of this equipment and a set of tools required to carry out routine maintenance shall be provided.

Extract from report from Mr. Johnston, District Engineer dated October 13th on the Rocher River Day School.

RE: ROCHER RIVER.

The 2 Classroom Day School and Teachers' Quarters has been erected and has outside finish on the walls and a built-up tar and gravel roof recently completed by a roofing contractor from Edmonton. The roughing-in has been done for electricity. The hot-air furnace and heating ducts are now being installed. It was not possible for the plumbing contractor to deliver materials to destination this year, owing, in part to the lateness in which the contract was let, and also to the fact that there are only about four boats per season from Fort Smith to this point. Carpenter work has advanced to a point where three carpenters could finish by early December. Work on this project was closed down for the season on the 16th instant, largely due to the impossibility of having a generator delivered which was necessary for operation of the blower in connection with the hot-air furnace. I wrote you by letter # 2961 on October 6th, in reference to specifications calling for a fully automatic electric generating machine and the reluctance of firms to supply this unit. I am still awaiting your instructions if a manually controlled machine could be installed.

So far as I know, no desks or classroom fittings have been received at Rocher River, and there is no furniture on hand for the teachers' quarters. In fact the arrival of these fittings, furniture and so forth, at a settlement where there is little, if any, warehouse storage space, presents a problem and it is doubtful if such should be delivered until the school building is ready to receive these articles, which represent a considerable investment. It should, however, be possible to begin work next spring on the school project and have it completed early in June when the first boat arrives there. Incoming shipments of furniture, classroom supplies, fittings, rations for the teacher and so forth should be scheduled to arrive on the first boat arriving at Rocher River next year. That would permit the opening of school by July 1st if this were desired.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Roche River Indian Day School.

In connection with Acting Director MacKay's memorandum to you of October 26th last, bearing your marginal notation thereon of the 27th, we make the following comments with regard to the electrical plant specified for the above school.

This Division prepared architectural, heating and electrical drawings, Index No. 860 and bill of materials for the construction of a Two Classroom Day School with Teachers' Residence for use at various locations in the Northwest Territories including the above.

Prior to the preparation of heating and electrical drawings, a conference was held at which decisions were reached in connection with the type of fuel to be used for heating purposes, and the type of electrical power supply to be provided in locations where a power source is not available.

The decisions reached are noted in Mr. Lamberton's memorandum No. 13272 dated April 14, 1948, which established that one 110 volt alternating current generating unit shall be provided for the Roche River School and also that wood fuel is to be used for heating.

Our electrical drawings were prepared as a standard and are applicable, in accordance with instructions contained in the bill of materials, for locations with or without electrical power supply.

Our heating plans were prepared using a forced hot air system automatically controlled by a room thermostat to maintain a pre-determined temperature. The bill of materials was based on oil fuel, the intention being that the necessary changes needed to burn any other fuel, would be furnished by letter, upon advice to this Division that construction of the building would be proceeded with in an area where a fuel other than oil was to be used.

To satisfy the requirements laid down by the heating design, it was necessary to have electrical energy available whenever the room temperature dropped below a pre-determined value, at any time in a 24 hour period during the heating season. To supply such a service with an alternating current type of generating unit, it is necessary that it be operated continually or that the unit be equipped with automatic controls to start the unit whenever power is required.

If we provided a continual operating source of A.C. power, it would be necessary to house the unit in a building isolated from the school to eliminate noise and it would also be advisable to
provide a standby unit. To keep our design in accordance with conditions laid down, it was necessary that an automatically controlled generating set be specified.

We included space on the rear of the school building to house the generator set, as it was felt that three or four short operating periods required during sleeping hours would not be a disturbing factor.

This Division is of the opinion that a 110 volt direct current storage battery electrical system would be more applicable to the site, as with this type of installation the generator set would be operated for charging purposes, only several times per week, and a supply of power would be available at all times. Due to the relatively small number of operating hours per week of this equipment, as compared with an alternating current unit, a standby generating unit is not considered a requisite. This system would also prove more economical from the standpoint of operation and maintenance.

The use of such equipment would eliminate the required automatic feature as specified, about which the manufacturers express concern because of the lack of electrical maintenance in this area in cases of breakdowns. We do not recommend a manually controlled A.C. set without a standby because it would, in all probability be run continually to furnish power as required for heating and lighting and the availability of maintenance service would be questionable.

It will be necessary to prepare new electrical drawings and bill of materials as well as specifications for electrical power plant if the above suggestions are adopted. Electrical equipment used in the heating system will have to be specified to suit the direct current power supply, as at present the equipment specified is based on a power source of 110/220 volts A.C.

The above suggestions are contrary to the decisions reached in this matter as outlined in Mr. Lamberton's memorandum, but we believe this system is better suited to the conditions than an alternating current installation and would prove more reliable than the manually controlled A.C. generating unit suggested by Mr. W. J. Johnston.

We have no information in connection with the progress of the construction and assume that the wiring changes necessary to convert from 3 wire 110/220 volt A.C. to 2 wire 110 volt D.C. and arrangements for the provision of different types of lighting fixtures can be made.

T. F. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

For your information. It is recommended that a D.C. Lighting Plant with batteries be provided for this school, and that the school be heated with wood fuel.

R. A. Gibson,
Director,

I am replying to your letters of December 23rd, 1948 and February 16th, 1949 in reference to electrical power to be supplied at school at Roher River, N.W.T.

Attached to letter of December 23rd was a memorandum prepared by T.E. Mills, Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources. Mr. Mills recommended that a direct current generating unit be supplied rather than the Alternating Current automatically controlled unit which had been earlier recommended.

Attached hereto is a cost estimate for a direct current power plant for Roher River. This estimate has been prepared by Mr. J.E. Kellett of this office.

When the decision is made to change from alternating current to direct current, it will be impossible to provide but very space, and also space for the direct current machinery, in the school building itself. It is thus necessary to take advantage of a warehouse building which was constructed for general storage, and to remodel same to house the direct current batteries and machinery.

The cost for a direct current set with batteries, as per attached estimate, is $6,222.29 for the purchase of equipment and its installation in the building at Roher River, ready to function. The life of batteries in a direct current installation is 360 chargings.

By comparison, I am attaching estimate herewith for the cost of the alternating current unit it was originally intended to install, namely:

CALL FOR QUOTATIONS FOR DIRECT CURRENT UNIT:

Call for quotations for the materials and equipment for a direct current installation including batteries, was made to six firms. Appendix "A" attached, gives a list of the firms asked to tender, and the results therefrom:

Mumford Medland Limited of Winnipeg, Manitoba, (a re-organization of Firm now bears the name of Medland Machinery Limited) submitted the lowest bid of $4,635.00. However, they quoted on a battery of only 250 ampere hours, and required six months' notice before delivery could be guaranteed.

(over)
The next highest tender was received from Bruce Robinson Electric Limited of Edmonton for $4,758.00. This firm quoted on a 450 ampere hour battery and promised delivery in from three to four weeks from receipt of order. I therefore recommend acceptance of the tender of Bruce Robinson Electric Limited for a price of $4,758.00 f.o.b., Waterways, Sales Tax included. This firm promise delivery in from three to four weeks and it is necessary to have shipment so forward from Waterways early in the season. I would therefore ask that I be notified by telegram as soon as approval is given for this purchase.

The original tender as obtained from Bruce Robinson Limited is attached hereto. I do not consider it necessary to send all the other tenders received, but these are on file here.

**CITATION OF DIRECT CURRENT AND ALTERNATING CURRENT UNITS:**

You will note from the above, that the D.C. Unit costs $8,822.29 as against $4,758.76 for an A.C. Unit. However, I believe it is the feeling in Ottawa that the lower maintenance costs of a direct current installation would more than pay the initial capital expense. That is a matter of electrical maintenance economics which I do not care to enter into, and am not thus expressing any opinion; In other words, the decision to switch from an alternating current to a direct current installation was made in Ottawa. Thus my recommendation for the purchase of a direct current installation and the acceptance of Bruce Robinson Electric Tender for $4,408.00 is only following out the decision handed me, to install a direct current machine.

I am replying to your letters of December 23rd, 1948 and February 16th, 1949 in reference to electrical power to be supplied at school at Rocher River, N.W.T.

Attached to letter of December 23rd was a memorandum prepared by T.E. Mills, Chief Engineer Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources. Mr. Mills recommended that a direct current generating unit be supplied rather than the Alternating Current automatically controlled unit which had been earlier recommended.

Attached hereto is a cost estimate for a direct current power plant for Rocher River. This estimate has been prepared by Mr. J.E. Kellett of this office.

When the decision is made to change from alternating current to direct current, it will be impossible to provide battery space, and also space for the direct current machinery, in the school building itself. It is thus necessary to take advantage of a warehouse building which was constructed for general storage, and to remodel same to house the direct current batteries and machinery.

The cost for a direct current set with batteries, as per attached estimate, is $8,823.29 for the purchase of equipment and its installation in the building at Rocher River, ready to function. The life of batteries in a direct current installation is 660 chargings.

By comparison, I am attaching estimate herewith for the cost of the alternating current unit it was originally intended to install, namely:

CALL FOR QUOTATIONS FOR DIRECT CURRENT UNITS:

Call for quotations for the materials and equipment for a direct current installation including batteries, was made to six firms. Appendix "A" attached, gives a list of the firms asked to tender, and the results therefrom:

Mumford Medland Limited of Winnipeg, Manitoba, (a re-organization of Firm now bears the name of Medland Machinery Limited) submitted the lowest bid of $4,635.00. However, they quoted on a battery of only 250 ampere hours, and required six months' notice before delivery could be guaranteed.

(over)
The next highest tender was received from Bruce Robinson Electric Limited of Edmonton for $4,798.00. This firm quoted on a 450 ampere hour battery and promised delivery in from three to four weeks from receipt of order. I therefore recommend acceptance of the tender of Bruce Robinson Electric Limited for a price of $4,798.00 f.o.b., Waterways, Sales Tax included. This firm promise delivery in from three to four weeks and it is necessary to have shipment go forward from Waterways early in the season. I would therefore ask that I be notified by telegram as soon as approval is given for this purchase.

The original tender as obtained from Bruce Robinson Limited is attached hereto. I do not consider it necessary to send all the other tenders received, but these are on file here.

COMPARISON OF DIRECT CURRENT AND ALTERNATING CURRENT UNITS:

You will note from the above, that the D.C. Unit costs $8,823.29 as against $4,798.76 for an A.C. Unit. However, I believe it is the feeling in Ottawa that the lower maintenance costs of a direct current installation would more than pay the initial capital expense. That is a matter of electrical maintenance economics which I do not care to go into, and am not thus expressing any opinion on; In other words, the decision to switch from an alternating current to a direct current installation was made in Ottawa. Thus my recommendation for the purchase of a direct current installation and the acceptance of Bruce Robinson Electric Tender for $4,798.00 is only following out the decision handed me, to install a direct current machine.

Dear Colonel Anderson:

Rocher River Indian Day School.

The Director of the Lands and Development Services Branch has forwarded to me a copy of the letter which you received from Mr. W.J. Johnston, your District Engineer in Edmonton, dated April 6, 1949, concerning the provision of an electrical generator for the above school.

Careful consideration has been given to the provision of either a direct current unit or an alternating current generator. We also feel that the extension necessary for the housing of the D.C. plant could have been made to the main building. However, we note that this is not now convenient, and that he intends to convert the warehouse previously constructed.

Sincerely yours,

Director.

Ottawa, 4 August, 1949.

Director
Indian Affairs Branch

Attention - Colonel Neary.

For your information, I am attaching herewith, copy of letter dated July 28th from District Engineer W. J. Johnston concerning an order for the oil supplies for the D.C. Generating set at Rocher River, N.W.T.

EVG/S.

R. Blais
Chief Engineer.
I refer to my telegram of July 26th and your telegram of July 27th in reference to purchase of Diesel oil and necessary lubricants for electric light plant at Roche River, N.W.T.

The reason I telegraphed you was to find out for sure if I should order this material, as Indian Affairs Branch had ordered the firewood for the wood-burning furnace. Roche River was the only place where a wood-burning furnace was installed, and all other schools burn oil. Thus there was no chance that when Indian Affairs Branch were ordering the firewood for the furnace they might also be ordering the oil supplies for the Direct Current Electric Generating set.

Your letter of December 22nd, 1948, gave instructions that oil for the first year's supply should be considered a charge against the construction programme. Thus from this letter I had the authority to make the purchase, but wanted to be positive there was no chance of duplication in ordering.

The amount of the order placed is $699.67, f.o.b., Waterways, Alberta, and freight and handling charges on same may bring the total purchase to $1,000 when delivered at school at Roche River.

Work was suspended on the school on July 31st but there are still some unfinished items of carpenter work remaining to be done due, in part, to the non-arrival of necessary hardware. Some ten days' work of a workman would complete the phase of the project. The Electric Generating set, although delivered and installed, is not fully operating possibly through unfamiliarity of the workmen sent in to set up this unit. I am having this matter checked on further when a starting motor arrives and some small expense will be required further, to complete this installation.

I shall let you know shortly if I require extra funds for the purchase of the Diesel oil and lubricants.

I am writing L.C. Hunter, Superintendent of Indian Agencies Fort Norman, sending a copy of the Purchase Requisition placed for the several grades of oil and lubricants. This will both advise him that the purchase has been made and also serve as a sample or types of oil and lubricants required for the D.C. Generating set when re-ordering of materials is necessary next year.

I would suggest this letter be drawn to the attention of Col. B.F. Henry, Department of Education, Indian Affairs Branch.

W.J. Johnston
District Engineer.

P.S. I presume the teachers at the various points where oil is being supplied are being instructed to apply for the refund on deposit which is available when empty steel drums are returned. The return will not be possible until next year.
August 15, 1949.

District Engineer,
Department of Public Works,

Edmonton, Alberta.

Memorandum

Col. E.F. Neary  
Superintendent, Education Service  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Department of Mines and Resources  
Ottawa

For your information we are forwarding to you herewith a copy of a report received from Mr. Fred Fraser, District Administrator, Fort Smith, Northwest Territories, relating to the school plant at Rocher River, Northwest Territories.

Deputy Commissioner
Mr. W. J. Johnston,
District Engineer,
Department of Public Works,
9357 - 103rd Street,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Johnston:

I was at Kocher River on the 28th of July last and left the package of filters which you sent for the lighting plant for the school.

George McCallum is acting as caretaker as you know. He appears capable and has a sense of responsibility.

I have the following comments to make about the building:

Living Quarters

Bathroom--The linoleum has not been laid although there is some available. The vent pipe for the plumbing fixtures passes through the floor and the ceiling and is open to view. It should be painted. The holes in the floor and ceiling were cut much too large and should be covered up with some kind of trim as they are very unsightly.

Living Room--There is a vent pipe that passes through this room which is open to view and should be painted. The holes through the floor and ceiling were very roughly cut and should be filled in or trimmed since a bad draft will come through them.

The hall and stairway from the lower floor to the living quarters, including all trim and doors, have been left unpainted.

South Bathrooms--There is a vent pipe open to view here also which should be painted. The holes in the floor and ceiling here too are much too large and should be filled in or trimmed.

Downstairs

The storeroom for school supplies, including the ceiling, should be painted. The school furniture is lying scattered around the rooms partly assembled. Assembling of the furniture should be completed. Furniture and supplies now stored with the Hudson's Bay Company and Mr. Defelt should be delivered to the school. The sliding doors were not installed properly and if an attempt is made to open them, they are more than likely to fall over and tear loose from the hinges. This should be investigated and the proper work carried out. Evidently some mistake was made in wiring the school and when the lighting switches were being tested, it was found that the hall lights did not operate. It was then necessary to cut a hole in the ceiling of the hall and this has been left uncovered. Possibly there was not sufficient plaster board left over to make a repair although something should certainly be done about it.

Power Plant Building

There was apparently not sufficient asbestos siding to complete two sides of this building. The interior should be painted. Has no arrangement been made for a stove for this building? If it is not properly heated, the batteries will freeze and the lighting plant will be of no use.
This is a Lister lighting plant than which there are none better made. A special arrangement is provided on this plant for starting the engine by throwing a switch which turns the generator into a motor; the current from the batteries turns the generator over and starts the engine. The wiring of this part has evidently been done wrong, because, when the switch is thrown the motor does not turn over and the battery terminals heat up so much that there is danger of their melting. Apparently the batteries are just shorting the current going to the motor. The electrician who did the job stated that he knew nothing whatever about this class of work. Although the engine is not difficult to start by hand, it requires two men to do so and I do not think the plant should be left as it is.

You should be sure that the watchman or caretaker has adequate instruction in the running of this plant. An ample supply of distilled water for refilling the batteries should be on hand as well as proper grade of lubricating oil for the machine. I would strongly recommend that a man completely familiar with the maintenance and operation of this plant be sent in to properly instruct the caretaker, otherwise we are liable to have the machine out of repair and this will entail heavy expense.

There is a small warehouse at the rear of the school in which is stored a certain amount of surplus material from construction. There is a considerable pile of other material including lumber, bricks and fencing lying outside which will disappear if not properly stored. I think there is room in the building for it and arrangements should also be made to look after it properly.

The school yard has been left littered with scrap ends of lumber and all of the miscellaneous left-over building materials. It is very unsightly and I certainly think it is the responsibility of your department, in constructing buildings, to clean up before you leave.

I am writing to our Head Office asking that proper arrangements be made for the employment of a caretaker.

Yours truly,

'sgi' Fred Fraser

Fred Fraser,
District Administrator.

Dear Sir:

I am replying to your letter of August 15th, advising that Mr. Blackburn and his wife were leaving Edmonton on August 20th for Rocher River. Actually Mr. and Mrs. Blackburn only arrived in Edmonton today and, according to present arrangements, are expected to arrive at Rocher River on September 1st. I have arranged the various train and airplane reservations for them via Fort Smith, N.W.T., and feel there will be no difficulty in their arrival.

The D.C. electric generating plant is not working satisfactorily, and the manufacturer's agents here of this plant have promised to send a representative to Rocher River to inspect it and put it in first-class running order. I am delaying the arrival of this mechanic until after Mr. and Mrs. Blackburn have arrived at Rocher River, in order that Mr. Blackburn may receive first-hand instructions.

Mr. Blackburn showed me a letter you had written him, and I gather it is the intention for Mr. Blackburn to assume the responsibility for the maintenance and operation of this D.C. electric generating plant. A man is presently looking after this unit and performing general watchman and janitor services while the building is unoccupied, but I am leaving the final permanent arrangements to be worked out by Mr. Blackburn after his arrival. I have also contacted the engineer of this Department at Yellowknife to discuss the matter with Mr. I. F. Kirkby of Indian Affairs Branch, Yellowknife. It is my understanding that the permanent arrangement regarding janitor services and a maintenance man for electric generating plant,

(OVER)
electrically controlled hot-air furnace and so forth, should be arranged for by Indian Affairs. However, any assistance possible the Public Works Department can give in effecting a smooth changeover from construction to maintenance, should be attempted, and we are trying to operate on this policy.

Yours very truly,

W. J. Johnston,

Dear Sir:

Attached please find Requisitions covering janitor supplies, noon lunch requirements and wood needed for the school term beginning Sept. 6th, 1949.

As at Hay River I do not believe that any of these items have been ordered and they are all urgently needed to start the school in operation. Items of supplies that are needed immediately will be purchased locally at the store until such time as the above order arrives.

The order if shipped immediately should be in time to catch the last boat of the Hudson's Bay into Rocher River this fall before freeze up. If not the shipment could be sent by boat as far as Fot Smith c/o Fred Fraser District Administrator and sent to Rocher River in small quantities whenever the Mines and Resources plane was making a trip to Yellowknife or other point in the North. In this way items could be put into a very out-of-the-way place at no extra cost. Most of the items with the exception of soap are not stocked at Rocher River and we must ship them in.

The cook stove at Rocher River is a wood burner and takes a fourteen inch stick. As all the wood in the yard is in four foot lengths for the furnace it will either be necessary to re-cut the wood or have a supply of cookstove wood brought in from the woods. If we cut the furnace wood up we may run short and be required to get more cut during the winter. As we will need wood for another season in any case I believe it would be more economical to have the wood cut and delivered directly as cook stove wood. I therefore request authority to cut ten cords stove wood at a cost of approx. $25.00 per cord.

The furniture and kitchen utensils supplied at this school is very skimpy and as at Hay River I believe we should put in a complete unit of standard equipment. I believe Mr. Martin was asked to submit a list and although he does not know what the list contained it is reasonable to expect that Rocher River should get the same. When I inspected the school last week it was noted that no dishes nor cutlery was delivered but that pots and pans had come. As the stores at Rocher do not stock dishes etc., it will be necessary to either ship them in by air immediately or purchase locally at Yellowknife and take them into the school first chance we have. Will it be in order for me to make these purchases or will it come from Edmonton.

No water system has as yet been installed but the Public works are to complete next summer and in the mean time enough old barrels can be found to hold water hauled from the river.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

CANADA
During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the school term I believe it worth while to report on my observations at each point.

On September 14th proceeded to Roher River with Agency boat. This school had opened for the first time on September the 6th, and was progressing very favourably. The day I attended this school 33 pupils were in attendance and a few more were expected to come in. For the most part this number or possibly a few more will be the limit. Some of these children will move out with their parents for the winter hunt but I believe well over 25 will be in attendance at all times.

The Superintendent of Indian Education was contacted and permission to construct a limited number of tables and benches to accommodate the extra pupils was obtained. These tables were to be so constructed that they can be used as ping-pong tables in a games room once more desks are obtained.

A large number, if not all the natives at this settlement are in the settlement for the greater part of the summer and now that we have a welfare teacher at this point, I believe we should encourage gardening, etc., if we are to improve the welfare of these natives. Mr. & Mrs. Blackburn are very enthusiastic about doing just this work and as we have a tractor at Resolution, I will have it taken to Roher River and plow up a section of the school yard as well as an area for communal gardens. It is my understanding that this type of work is part of the Welfare teachers job and in this country the first requirement is to improve the Indians standard of living by better methods of obtaining his food and clothing. A request for rakes and hoes for the spring gardening was noted and is on attached requisition.

As to Mr. Blackburn's status, it is obvious that he expects
to be second teacher when there are over 30 pupils and wants to hire a man to haul water, carry in wood and do the janitor jobs. I understood that Mr. Blackburn was to look after the school and we were not going to hire a janitor. From my talks with him I gathered that he felt that the teaching of the extra pupils and the night classes he took made it impossible to do the janitor work. As Mrs. Blackburn is the welfare teacher, I thought it was her place to teach the older persons and to contact the Indians in the settlement.

Both these people seem enthusiastic and should, I hope, help to make Roche River a better place for the Indians. I would at the same time like to know whether we are to hire the services of an extra man as janitor. I cannot see how two teachers on full time pay are needed to teach 30 pupils, but can be corrected.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last term and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

(Sgd.) I.E.Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

The above was issued in favour of the Hudson's Bay Company, and on their account dated September 30th, amounting to $194.50, the following items appear:

Radiogram to Waterways re luggage 1.75
Radiogram to Edmonton re Mess supplies 5.50
Radiogram to Edmonton re cancellation of Mess Order 1.75

The above items are unusual charges, and we would appreciate having some information about them so that we can decide if the Department is liable for their payment.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST
Supt. of Indian Education
Dear Sirs:

We have for the short time the Rocher River school has been in operation been having constant trouble with the light plant as supplied for this school. The last power failure being when one battery post was burned off.

As it was necessary for me to make a trip into this Settlement I had Mr. W. Smith of Yellowknife Electric go in to give the plant a check before any more damage was done. When we examined the plant we found the following defects that were due to faulty installation and nothing else.

(a) All battery cells were set up and the posts still had paint and dirt from packing still on them.
(b) All connectors were dirty some with paper still on and all had been coated with vaseline before being fastened to cell post.
(c) Five cells in the middle of the bank were reversed so that we had 90 volts instead of 112 volts.
(d) With low voltage the points of the reverse relay cut-out were fused and were fixed until new arrive.
(e) Several cell posts had started to burn but after cleaning were servicable.

With cells set up and no paint or dirt removed from post and with the addition of vaseline between post and connector a resistance was set up that burned off the one post and started to burn several others. The posts were all cleaned and connected. Several iron bolts were used in place of lead and copper ones. One afternoon was spent cleaning up battery bank.

Five cells were put in backwards and this reduced voltage to 90 volts. This was corrected and the fact that the plant was not in operation was all that saved these five cells from being ruined. It appeared as though these cells are still good but will report on them later if they do not hold charge.

With the low voltage at the cut out when starting and stopping the points were almost completely burned off and were fixed for the present until new ones are sent in. These points fused and would not cut out the first time we tried the motor after the battery bank was cleaned and put in operation.

The new cell has not arrived at Rocher River at the present time but I picked up the burned cell and will forward to you from Yellowknife, this will enable you to get it before it would have been available through Ft. Smith.

Please send in the following parts to me at Yellowknife so that I can take them into Rocher River on my next trip in.

6 Battery connector strips, to replace burned out ones.
6 Battery post bolts & nuts, Lead & copper. For connecting end cells to line etc.
12 Lugs for line wire and cross connection.

1 Set, Reverse Current Relay Points., No name on panel board but presume you know the type. Possibly one complete cutout would be better and we can return old one to you.
I believe that this information covers the defects that have been encountered so far and I might add that since returning to Yellowknife I received a wire from the Teacher at Roche River stating that the plant was operating very satisfactorily and all the troubles seemed to be eliminated.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of October 14th., file 910-5 (El) regarding the three Radiograms listed on my Voucher No. 148 I have the following explanation.

When the Blackburns arrived at Roche River there was no sign of mess supplies nor their baggage and in the confusion they wired, first to Waterways about their baggage to make sure that it arrived at Ft. Smith in time to be picked up by the Mines and Resources Plane.

When no order could be found covering rations for the coming winter they wired someone in Edmonton to send in an order and then when the Invoice arrived for their ration they had to send a wire to cancel the first one.

I presume that these were moving in expenses and as such were charged against the Branch. It may be that these items should have been charged against Mrs. Blackburn's travelling expenses and not on the account that I rendered.

If the above three wires are considered a charge against Mrs. Blackburn and not payable by the Indian Affairs Branch I will advise the Blackburns accordingly.

Yours very truly,

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Freeze up on the lake was late this year and it has only been within the last week that we could fly from the North side of the lake to the south shore. I made a trip into Rocher River yesterday and can make the following report on this school.

The heating of this school is very unsatisfactory and it is almost impossible to keep the class rooms warm enough to even stay in them for an hour at a time. The forced air does not seem to be working at top performance and I will write Mr. W.J. Johnston of Dept. of Public Works to see if he can suggest anything. The furnace jacket itself was too hot to put ones hand on it but little heat seemed to get into the rooms. The floors are too cold to put your hand on them and in all the wash rooms the water in the barrels is freezing and any water spilled on the floors freezes at once. With this wood furnace the heat is there because the jacket and duct for some distance is hot but if we cannot find the trouble there is no way of keeping the school warm once it gets down to fifty or sixty below.

At this point the Dept. of Public Works left many small things undone when they left with the understanding that they were to return next summer to complete the painting, put in the water system and complete the floors. Here as well as at Hay River there is no water except what is hauled from the river and all that can be heated to wash the floors is what can be heated on the small cook stove in the teachers residence. This makes it impossible to scrub floors when it would take several pails to do the job. The water would also freeze to the floor before it could be wiped up. Mr. W.J. Johnston stated that these hardwood floors should not be scrubbed if possible.

Mr. McKinnon complained about the dirt but as we do not have polishers or wakers at this point, not is the varnish jobs completed it is much exaggerated. The Ft. Smith and the Yellowknife schools are held up as examples but the point that at these points the schools have been going for some years, power and power polishers have always been used, running hot water can be had by turning a tap and the local conditions of pure sand or gravel make untold differences. I know that the Administration schools are being held up as such good examples and how poor the Indian Affairs are but once we have been in operation as long as the others we will be just as good or possibly a little better when we take into account the type of workmanship that went into some of our buildings.

The furniture at Rocher River is very skimpy and it is very poor in quality as compared to the Administration school of the same type at Resolution that just opened up. I realize better than some of our critics that we cannot get supplies into Rocher River except during the summer and we must therefore make the best of what we have. I am enclosing
a list of items that were ordered from Eaton's catalogue and which should be sent into Roche River next summer. The teacher will no doubt change from time to time and we should not have to move any furniture for them but supply it all. I feel that a washing machine is a must and that it should be used in her Welfare work if need be. The refrigerator is also needed as one was supplied in the new Administration school at Resolution.

The Blackburn's are using boxes to add to their book shelf space and also for many other purposes. I have enclosed a list of what is supplied and though it is meager I believe that the Teacher understands the problem at Roche River and that it will be remedied next summer. Here again I feel that once we have furnished the residence that so long as we are sure that the building and contents are being maintained in good condition then the residence is the man's own home. He is paying rent for it and officials should not barge through every or any room except by permission.

Mr. Blackburn is to do all the janitor work and look after the maintenance of the light plant as well as to assist with the Welfare work of the community. Mr. Blackburn will not run the light plant himself but as he is paid for this work then he can pay another party to do the job and we only have to hold Blackburn responsible.

The water and wood must be hauled for some little distance and I have authorized him to hire an Indian to do the job. This work must be done by dog team and cannot be expected of the man.

At Roche River we have two factions, one the Hudson's Bay trader and the other a free trader. In between there is a group of no good white trash who are dead beats anywhere. To establish a school board of this type of person down in a community such as this will only give the teacher untold grief. None of the whites are out of the feeding, which is in no uncertain terms and the Bay Manager is just as much a part of the whole thing as any one else. Even the Police dislike going to Roche River because all one hears is a long series of fantastic tales about one party when he visits one store and then hears equally as fantastic from the other store when he visits it. To make the teacher responsible to any of these individuals would be to drive him out by the first plane.

The above probably does not interest you but it is one of my objections to having a trustee out of the Roche River whites appointed. If these people were a little more interested in the school and incidently the Indians than they are about their own fairy tales, which do cause plenty of trouble then I would be in favor of a trustee but not the way things stand. A trustee from any section of the Roche River whites would be a stool pigeon who would haunt the teacher day and night.

I feel the school work is progressing very favorably and the Indians seem only too willing to attend. There is no trouble with them and all social activities are very orderly and very well attended by these people. The only ones who do not seem to know their places are some of the whites who as in most places have been the real offenders where it comes to bringing alcohol to the Indians. I think this is answering a long felt need in Roche River and if the Teacher can be kept out of the petty jealousy that exists then we need not worry about the final outcome being a success.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Agencies.

On Nov. 25th I received a wire from the teacher at Roche River school complaining about the heating of this building. For the wires it was not possible to determine the causes so while in Roche last week I made an examination of the heating unit and have the following report to make.

The class rooms and all the cloak rooms did not have circulation enough to be able to keep them either warm enough for classes or, in some cases, above freezing. The floors of the class rooms were too cold to hold your hand on for any length of time and the blackboards at the far end of the room were cold at all times. In the wash rooms and the cloak room halls it was impossible to raise the temperature above the freezing point and there was over an inch of ice on the water barrels and any water that spilled on the floors froze at once.

I checked the furnace itself and as the wood burned at this point is fire killed spruce and jack pine there was an abundance of heat right at the furnace. I have been assured that fires are kept on all day and that at night fires are stoked up at ten or eleven and started again at four in the morning. I do not believe that the fault lies with the fires in the furnace but in the air circulating system.

I went to all registers and, for the amount of fire, there was not the amount of hot air coming through that should have been. I did not have any heating plant and some registers in unused rooms were closed off to try and get heat into the class rooms but even there the heat was limited. The hot air seemed to be available at many registers but the cold air would not return to the furnace.

The furnace hot air jacket was too hot to put one's hand on and the hot air duct the full length of the furnace room was hot. From this I would presume that there could be some obstruction in the cold or hot air ducts or that the circulating fan is running too slow. I am sure now that the trouble does not lie in the wood burner itself.

As no circulation seemed possible before the teacher opened the class room door and the door between the hall and the furnace room, this put two doors opposite open and then they took the back of the air conditioner off exposing the fan. In this way the cold air return was through the doors and not though the cold air return. This had been done the day before I was there and this was the warmest the school had been for weeks. I felt that the cold air return must be faulty but I could not say where. The above arrangement does get heat into the class rooms but all the other cloak rooms and halls are below freezing.

On the day before I checked Roche River I went into
Ft. Resolution and here the class rooms and all the building was too hot for comfort even though the furnace was not on full. When standing out in the centre of the class rooms one could feel the hot air blowing in his face while at Roche River even with your face right up to the register there wasn't as much heat coming out.

There is no reason why the wood furnace should not give out as much heat as the oil burner and if the installation of all ducts were the same in both schools I believe the same heat should be available. We have no Engineer nor anyone who knows the first thing about it at Roche River, therefore it will be necessary to take a man from here if I can get one.

If you can suggest any remedies that might be applied to this unit we will try them out as it is not going to be possible to operate this building once the weather drops below -40 below without some changes.

At the present time Mr. MacCallum checks the light plant and does a few odd jobs around but from what I have seen of him I am sure that he would deliberately prevent it from working and I do not believe he is capable of doing any repair work of any importance for us. Some of the trouble might be eliminated if one were to experiment with the system, but as no one in Roche has any ideas or is of any help I feel an Engineer should spend a couple of days in this school when the weather is below -40 degrees and then he can either correct the faults or give an accurate report on why the system does not work, something that no one knows now.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. B.F. Neary our Supt. of Education and if you feel that you can offer any explanations he will be pleased to hear from you direct.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Since commencement of operation of the Rocher River School light plant much difficulty has been experienced in the operation and early in October I made a trip into this school with Mr. Will Smith, Manager of the Yellowknife Power Company and many of our difficulties were found to be due to faulty installation. I wrote Bruce Robinson Electric on Oct 13th, my file #139-6-1, Rocher River and explained all the faults found, copy of this letter was sent to you at that time.

At the time it was thought that the low voltage had only burned the relay points but this unit has never worked since and later was found to be completely burned out. I wired Bruce Robinson for a new part and this is covered in Voucher #315. I believe this repair was necessary through faulty installation and not faulty maintenance and should be supplied free by the supplier of the equipment. If you feel this is the case will you please contact Bruce Robinson Electric Ltd. before making payment.

RATIONS - INDIAN DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS

At some of the settlements in the Northwest Territories the assortment of groceries and provisions available for purchase is rather limited. In many cases, the stocks are meagre and there is little variety in the items offered.

To overcome this situation and as a measure of assistance to the teachers, arrangements have been made with the Hudson's Bay Company to have requisitions for rations filled at Edmonton and shipped directly to the individual teacher.

The Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare has prepared a ration list of the items required for one person living for one year in the North. We have secured approximate prices as quoted by the Hudson's Bay Company in Edmonton. Attached is this list, with the prices, of course, being subject to variation.

On the basis of this list the teacher may then prepare an order and forward same to this office. We will then place the order with a wholesale grocery firm in Edmonton and the items will be shipped by water transportation. The cost at wholesale price of the rations purchased in this manner on behalf of the teacher, together with transportation charges on same, will be deducted on a monthly basis from the living allowance paid to northern employees of the Department. The maximum that can be deducted from the Northern Living Allowance is $35. a month (i.e.) $350. for Day School Teachers and $20. from Welfare Teachers. In cases where the cost of the rations and transportation charges is in excess of the above possible deductions, the teacher will be obliged to pay the difference.

The requisition showing the requirements must reach Ottawa prior to March 15, 1950, complete with express address and shipping instructions to ensure delivery during the navigation season.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find vouchers #7 & 8 covering local purchases of miscellaneous supplies for the Rocher River Indian Day School.

As most of these supplies were breakable and the chance of delivery by boat was not too good without breakages these items have been delivered by myself when making a trip into this point on inspection duties.

Yours very truly,

T.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.
Dear Sir:

During the past week I was able to make a trip into Pecher River and the school there is not being held at this time. I was able to inspect the building both in maintenance and to amount of supplies used and any possible shortages that might occur during the coming season.

With regard to fuel and light supplies requisitioned for on my annual estimate I note that the light plant has not used a fraction of the fuel oil sent in last fall and at this school we still have enough to last us for two or three years. It would appear that the item for fuel oil be deleted but that the lubricants etc., be delivered as requested. On the same sheet I had requisitioned for sixty cords of wood for the furnace but now that the winter is over we find it takes more than expected and the wood item should be increased to eighty cords of furnace wood.

The establishment seems to be operating satisfactorily now and once the D.P. Works complete their painting and the installation of the water system next summer we should have little complaint with the exception of the wood floors which are going to be a source of irritation for the life of the building. The floors that were put in were hardwood that was not thoroughly dry and since being put down has shrunk so that many of the cracks are very wide and unsightly. This floor was only given one coat of light varnish, which wore off in a very short time and with the weekly scrubbing that is necessary to keep the place clean, the wood floor is wearing out real more year than it should and is rapidly deteriorating. There is a great deal of conflicting views as to the best method of preserving these floors and if they are not scrubbed spotless there is a section that complains that the teacher is not keeping the place respectable and another section who complain that the floors are being ruined because they are scrubbed. It is unfortunate that the floors were not battleproof linoleum as are all the Government offices, which incidentally do not receive one quarter as much wear as the school floors.

The floors at Pecher River are in need of immediate refinishing and I would request that an order be placed for twenty (20) gallons of Florence light oak varnish to be shipped by reach Waterways not later than June 5th, 1930. As I believe D.P. Works will be working at this school early in the season it might be possible to have them do the varnishing of the floors while they are there.

My former requisitions did not include this item as the teacher had not requested it and it is not apparent that we must have it for the floors as soon as possible.
Enclosed please find my supplementary requisition for varnish and brushed that were omitted from the last orders sent in early in the month.

A great deal of difficulty is being experienced at this school in keeping the children conscious of the value of cleanliness and of keeping a clean and tidy school. At this point all the pupils regret having to clean up at close of school and have shown open opposition to being made to clean up before entering the building. This is, as far as I am concerned, indicative of the home life and training of the Indians and has made life very unpleasant for the school teacher.

My letter of December 14th, this file outlined the conflict between the advocates of scrubbing the floors and those against it which is still going on.

It is the intention at this point to hold school all summer but as this is a two room school there is no reason why one class room cannot be completed while the other is being used and then make the change. This is going to inconvenience the carpenters who will be back to finish the job but as we have put up with a half finished job all year they should not complain for a few weeks.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

T.E. Orkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

With reference to my voucher #127 returned because no expenditure authorization was quoted I wish to advise that as no water system has ever been installed at this school and with the need of considerable water for many uses this school has been supplied all winter and spring with water hauled by a local man who has a team and at the end of each month the bill has been forwarded for payment.

As water must be supplied to any school I considered this a legitimate charge against the money estimated for the normal operation of these schools and as no authorization has been sent for this necessary service the vouchers have been sent without these.

A number of small items must be purchased each month to keep these large schools running and as these necessary purchases are always kept to a minimum they have been forwarded for payment.

Dear Colonel Neary:

The following extracts from reports received from Mr. I.M. Marshall of our Engineering and Construction Service, who made an inspection trip to the Mackenzie District this summer, are forwarded for your information. They refer to the school buildings constructed by the Department of Public Works for the Indian Affairs Branch.

"Rocher River School - Both Rocher River and Fort Resolution have the same fault in the double doors of the school. Both, also, have a more marked gap on the southerly side. They will all need attention before winter.

The reason the Rocher River school was so cold last winter was because the plumber removed some of the shiplap and insulation and did not replace it. It is replaced now."

"Fort Norman School - In the school the accordion doors cannot be locked as the floor has dropped so that the bolts will not engage. The two doors at the back entrance will not close by three inches even though they were planed off by the Dept. of Public Works less than a month ago. This is another school erected by D.P.W. on concrete blocks, 6 feet deep, (a scant five feet buried) four feet square at the base and one foot square on top. My investigation showed five feet before frost was encountered. Dept. of Public Works started to put in a septic tank in June but abandoned the effort at about 3/2 feet of depth."

Yours very truly,

R.A. Gibson,
Director.

August 23rd, 1950.

Mr. I.F. Kirkby,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Yellowknife, N.W.T.

"Rocher River School - Both Rocher River and Fort Resolution have the same fault in the double doors of the school. Both also have a more marked gap on the southerly side. They will all need attention before winter.

The reason the Rocher River School was so cold last winter was because the plumber removed some of the shiplap and insulation and did not replace it. It is replaced now."

You can arrange to have the double doors fixed.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total No. of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate No. of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total No. of days in quarter."

9. The amount of per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant No. 141-2-5, and as requested I have arranged with the R.A. Lister Company to have a man proceed to the Blood School at once, and dismantle and crate the lighting plant for shipment to the address given in your letter.

The batteries will be recharged before shipment, and I have requested the man who is undertaking the work to make sure that after they are charged they will give 100% efficiency, as it would be a serious mistake to send batteries to this remote point that were not in A1 shape.

I expect that the cost will be in the neighborhood of $150.00, although I cannot say for sure; this is just an estimate. I am issuing a transport Requisition to cover the freight, and I presume this will be satisfactory.

I presume you have made arrangements to have this plant installed at Aklavik. If not, the Lister Company tell me they can send a first-class man up to do it at a reasonable figure.

Ottawa, May 19, 1931.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have to inform Your Lordship that this Department is arranging to have a generating plant, complete with batteries, which is surplus to requirements at the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve, forwarded to Aklavik, for use in the Indian Residential School at that point. This plant is now being crated and will go forward to Waterways and thence by boat to Aklavik this summer.

I would request that Your Lordship arrange to have a lay brother, who is competent to do the work, install this equipment when it arrives at Aklavik. The batteries for this plant have been recharged and all equipment put in good condition, and Your Lordship will understand that if the plant is not properly installed serious damage would occur in the running down of the batteries, and it would be very difficult to have them recharged.

It is hoped that, when this equipment arrives and is installed, it will prove entirely satisfactory for lighting purposes at the Aklavik Indian Residential School.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian school, which were recently shipped to Waterways for transhipment to Aklavik. I regret to state that when the Northern Waterways Limited took over the consignment they found that the liquid in some of the containers had been spilled owing to the loss of stoppers and that one of the cases was definitely in bad order, the container itself being badly damaged and one of the batteries inside being broken.

The Winnipeg Manager of R.A. Lister and Company was in town and called at my office this afternoon. He informs me that the damage will not affect the utility of the plant. The actual extent of the damage however will not be known until the consignment reaches Aklavik, but I thought it as well to forewarn you in case of any complaint which might reach the Department from the school authorities there. I am definitely assured by the Lister people's representative that the shipment was carefully packed and left Cardston in good order. They state that Mr. Pugh supervised the packing and can vouch for the care which was taken. It is most unfortunate therefore that after all these precautions had been taken prior to shipment the plant should reach Waterways in a defective condition. The Lister Company will write me a letter setting out their case and the cost of the batteries which have been damaged, and upon receipt of these I will lodge a claim against the carriers.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

June 9th, 1933

Educational Department,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

I am informed that the Department of education is willing to help with expenses, if any, toward educating the little native children in the north. We have a Movie Camera, DeVry, commercial size, and as the Mission has electric lights and large rooms and nicely fixed to show pictures, but have no projector, would be only too pleased to show our film if they had a projector to fit our Camera.

We have pictures of the reindeer, that are stationed at present near Thistle Point, came from Alaska, 2000 of them, bought by the Canadian Government, to be placed on east side of Mackenzie delta to feed the Eskimo when in need.

We also have pictures of Herschel Island, the boats that land there and the Yukon hills, the boats that come and go up and down the river to Fort Smith.

I am speaking in behalf of the Mission. They know how much it would please their children, and if we can do anything to help this good work are only too glad.

We have a good business here have been here many years, and am in hope of being here many more.

Hoping this will meet with your approval, and will wait for a favorable reply.

I am yours sincerely,

V. Koest.

Reverend Father Director of Residential School of Aklavik is very glad to give his approval to the request of Mr. V. Koest. He thinks it would be of great utility for the education of the children of the school to show the movies which Mr. Koest is speaking about. Perhaps, would it be possible, afterwards, to get some films suitable for that projector from Educational Department. I heard Educational Department is willing to help us in this way of training the children of Northwest Territories.

Father Servinot,
R.C. Mission, Aklavik.

Dear Sir,

Ref.: Your file I4I-2-5

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 21st ultimo to which were attached accounts received from our Aklavik Residential School for the payment of the night watchman.

You intimate that vouchers for such accounts should come from my office and not from the school and you regret the complications caused by the school forwarding these accounts direct to you. May I say that I am somewhat surprised of your letter. In fact this is the first intimation I ever received regarding this matter. Your office is aware that all accounts for the night watchman's services at any of the four residential schools located in the Mackenzie Diocese have always been forwarded direct by the school to Ottawa without my interference in this matter. Payments used to be made to the R.C. Episcopal Corporation of Mackenzie through our Bank in Edmonton, and none of the above said accounts passed through my office.

As I do not know for what reason exactly you wish me sending vouchers for the services of the night watchman at the Indian Residential School of Aklavik, I would appreciate it if you would kindly have your attention directed again to this matter and whatever will be your decision, I shall gladly comply with it after having informed our schools of the wishes of the Department.

The accounts sent with your letter are returned herewith in order that you may have them for your files. The cheque of $120.00 has been received lately.

Respectfully yours,

Father J. Serrurot, O.M.I.,
Bursar, R.C. Missions of Mackenzie.

DEPUTY MINISTER

P.C. 40/1628 of June 24, 1939, approved payment of the under-mentioned amounts which have been provided in the current year's appropriation for the schools mentioned:

Aklavik R.C. Residential School ... $700.00

All of the above-mentioned schools are in the Diocese of Most Reverend G. Breynst, O.M.I., Archbishop of McKenzie, and his Bursar has submitted for payment an account of $1024.00 covering the cost of a Kelvinator unit purchased by the Archdiocese from the Somerville Company, Edmonton, Alberta, for use at the Aklavik R.C. Residential School. In submitting this account the Bursar writes in part as follows:

"We know that the amounts appropriated for the Providence Mission will be all required for the payment of the electrical installation at the school there.

"We have no special equipment or repairs at the Fort Resolution Indian School that would justify spending the amounts voted for that school.

"On the other hand, we feel confident that your Department will give favourable consideration to the amount spent at the Indian School of Aklavik for a..."
kelvinator unit bought on August 22nd last at the price of $1,024, as per receipted invoices enclosed herewith.

"We are aware that the purchase of this material should have been done through your purchasing branch. Nevertheless, as you will realize from the enclosed letter of the Sommerville Co., we felt that there was no other means for our school to have this equipment before freeze-up than to buy it according to the quotations given by the Sommerville Company.

"Your Branch knows how far distant from the railway Aklavik is located. Consequently, we could not take the risk of having this necessary equipment delayed for another year owing to the time required for correspondence between your purchasing department and our office and the number of weeks required for transportation.

"We hope that with the $700. voted for Aklavik and the $324. taken out of the Fort Resolution appropriation, you will have no difficulty in refunding us for the expenses incurred at Aklavik this year.

"Kindly have the cheque in settlement of this account addressed to the R.C. Episcopal Corporation of MacKenzie, c/o Banque Canadienne Nationale, Edmonton, Alberta."

I recommend that favourable consideration be given to payment of this account and in order to do so I enclose Memorandum to Council authorizing transfer of $324.00 from the amount provided for the Fort Resolution Residential School to the Aklavik R.C.
