Dear Mr. Phelan:

Further to your letter of the 20th ult., and to our reply of the 24th, we thought advisable to write you again in connection with repairs and equipment for the Aklavik R.C.Mission Residential School.

In the above mentioned letter, you informed us that there was a sum of $300, appropriated for repairs and improvements, also $500, for a refrigerator at Aklavik.

On the other hand, when we wrote you on October 21st last, we attached to our letter a list of material needed for repairs and equipment.

It appears to us that in this list which we presume you still have in your files, the material listed under the heading (1) would practically cover the whole amount appropriated for that school.

For this reason, we would appreciate if it would be possible for you to have this material ordered as soon as possible and overlook the balance of material listed under the heading (2).

For reference, we attach hereto a copy of our list of October 21st, 1940.

Your advice as to what you have decided in this connection would be very much appreciated.

Thanking you in anticipation for the favourable consideration you will give to our request, we are,

Yours very truly,

THE R. C. EPISCOPAL CORPORATION OF MACKENZIE,

Dear Sister:

On the requisition which you recently forwarded for supplies for the Aklavik R.C. School you request 12 new desks, also 4 fronts, 4 rears and 2 teacher's desks and chairs. School desks are difficult to obtain at the present time and before ordering them I desire to know if they are really necessary for the Indian children at the Aklavik R.C. School. R.A. Hoey, Supt.
Dept. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Answering your letter of the 12th. inst., which has just come to hand, would say that we are really in great need of the desks we are asking the Department to supply our school.

Although we have had only 24 Indian pupils enrolled this year, please note that we also had 40 Eskimos and 5 day scholars, besides 7 boarders. I beg to state also that the teachers have never been supplied with desks and chairs. In one of the classes, the teacher's desk is a kitchen table which has become very shaky with age. In the other class, the teacher's desk is a home-made one which would be better placed in another department in our school.

Trusting that you will see fit to procure these desks for us as requested and thanking you for past favors,

I beg to remain,

Yours respectfully,

Sister J. Duesault
Irin.
Ottawa,
April 9, 1943.

Mr. A.L. Cumming, Supt. Mackenzie District and Secretary Yukon Affairs, Lands, Parks & Forests Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

On a recent requisition Sister J. Dussault, Principal of the Aklavik R.C. Indian Residential School, requested 4 single school desks No. 5, 4 No. 4, 4 No. 3, 4 fronts No. 5, 4 rears No. 3, 2 teacher's desks and 2 teacher's chairs. The December quarter return only showed 24 Indian children enrolled at the school and our records indicate that we have supplied desks for all the Indian children. We wrote to Sister Dussault on March 12, 1943, for an explanation regarding her request. We have just received a letter from her dated March 24, copy of which I enclose. From this letter it would appear that in addition to the 24 Indian pupils enrolled as residential school pupils, there are 5 day pupils, a total of 29 Indian children for whom, as stated above, our records indicate we have supplied desks. It would, therefore, appear that the desks are being requested for the 40 Eskimos and the 7 boarders. I presume that the latter means white children. Under the circumstances I am submitting the request to you for your consideration.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Referring to your memorandum of April 9 addressed to Mr. Cumming, this Administration does not furnish equipment for any of the day or residential schools of the Northwest Territories. Our assistance is confined to payment of grants of $200 per annum for day schools operated in Indian or southern territory, $250 for day schools maintained in Eskimo or northern areas, $400 for all residential schools and expendable school supplies.

If a departure were made in the case of the Aklavik R.C. residential school it would mean that we would be called upon to furnish equipment for the other schools as well.

R. A. Gibson,
Director.
Ottawa,
April 17, 1943.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

We have had considerable correspondence with the Principal of the Aklavik R.C. Residential School requesting 4 single school desks No. 5, 4 No. 4, 4 No. 3, 4 fronts No. 5, 4 rears No. 3, 2 teacher's desks and 2 teacher's chairs. There are only 24 Indian pupils at this school and, while our records may not be exactly accurate, they indicate that we have supplied desks for the Indian children. It would, therefore, appear that these extra desks must be required for Eskimos or white children. I took up the matter with the Northwest Territories Branch, but they state they do not supply desks at residential schools.

Even if the desks were installed they would involve a considerable expenditure and would reduce the amount available for repairs and improvements at this school during the fiscal year 1943-44. If the desks were supplied, there would likely be considerable trouble having them transported to Aklavik this summer, as the boats will probably be busy. Under the circumstances I thought it advisable to submit the matter to you for your opinion.

Bishop Trocellier was in the Department recently and requested beds for one of the schools in the Diocese. I am not certain whether it was Holy Angels, Providence Mission, Fort Resolution or Aklavik. I should appreciate it if you would let me know which school it is, also the number necessary. Beds are difficult to obtain and practically the only size available is 6' x 3'. It is,

Rev. R.L. Lafleur, O.M.I.,

If you have this account I would appreciate it if you would certify and forward immediately.

......2
For materials ordered in early winter of 1945 did not reach us until the books for the year 1944-45 had been closed and consequently we were obliged to pay them from the current year's appropriation.

In view of the above situation, we will be obliged to use the unexpended balance of $656.54 of the three schools first mentioned to offset part of the over-expenditure of $907.93 at Fort Resolution, consequently we are not in a position to incur further expenditure at these four schools during the current fiscal year.

However, the requests made on the requisition lists which you sent from Fort Smith are being included in our estimates for the fiscal year 1946-47. If they are approved by the Minister we will be in a position to place the orders early in 1946 but until our estimates for 1946-47 are approved no action can be taken. I can assure you that I will keep the matter in mind and if the approval is granted, the necessary action will be taken to order the supplies requested.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Providence Mission, Holy Angels, Aklavik and Fort Resolution Indian Residential Schools.

We have your memorandum of November 7th with reference to our requisitions of October 25th for a precision light weight portable power chain saw for each of the above mentioned schools.

As pointed out in our requisitions it has become increasingly difficult for these schools to secure wood due to the scarcity and high price of labour. We feel that it would be advisable to supply a saw to each of these schools and the funds for the purpose are available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48. The necessary order in council has already been secured authorizing disbursement of the amounts specifically provided in the estimates. This type of saw is especially useful in the districts in which these schools are located and should serve for many years.

I would like to recommend immediate purchase.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NE

Re: Aklavik Residential Schools.

For several years the Department refused to recognize the Aklavik R.C. Residential School. Our files, therefore, show no record of its construction. Right Reverend Bishop Breynet, O.M.I., in a letter dated October 6, 1923 offered to build a residential school to accommodate up to thirty pupils for a grant of $30,000. He stated that with the help that was available such as carpenters and engineers he was able to construct the school for the above amount. This is the only reference to the cost of either of these schools. The only reference we have of the Church of England school is that on February 3, 1938 we gave them a grant for equipment of $2,000.00.

A.J. Bennett,
Supervisor, Training Division.

Ottawa, March 26, 1949.

Re: R.C. Indian Residential School

In a memorandum under date of the 23rd instant regarding the above, this office advised you that additional information was being sought regarding the likelihood of obtaining electrical power from the local privately owned plant.

Replying to a telegram on the matter, Bishop Trossellier wired Col. Henry of Indian Affairs as follows:

"Aklavik Town power twenty cents per K.W. very expensive we would save money with our own diesel plant STOP If Aklavik Power Company gives more reasonable prices we could take power there and then give the diesel plant to our Residential School of Providence"

At Aklavik, in addition to the R.C. school, another Indian Residential School is operated by the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada. Canon Cook, Superintendent of the Indian School Administration, R.S.C.C., was contacted by Col. Henry, for information in connection with the matter of power, and conditions which likely apply to both schools, were described by Canon Cook as follows:

The Aklavik Power and Supply Co., Ltd., has two diesel operated machines, with a capacity of 37½ K.W. each. The Company has in mind adding a third unit, which would raise capacity to between 80 and 90 K.W.

Mr. Puffer of the power company canvassed the Church of England school authorities and offered to supply 110 volt, single phase 60 cycle A.C. power for a flat rate of $175.00 per month, provided the school load did not exceed 3240 kilowatt hours per month. The company would install power line, transformers and meter if required. Charges for metered current would be as follows:

| Current for Power Operated Equipment | Current for Lighting Purposes |
|--------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Up to 100 K.W.H.                     | 10¢ per K.W.H.                |
| From 100 to 200 K.W.H.               | 15¢ per K.W.H.                |
| Above 200 K.W.H.                     | 16¢ per K.W.H.                |

This office has never been in possession of record drawings or data in connection with either of the schools mentioned, and Indian Affairs are unable to furnish data on the demand imposed. Consequently we are not in a position to make an intelligent recommendation on the action that should be taken until a thorough inspection of the R.C. residential school has been carried out, and an investigation of possible arrangements with the power company made. To date no request for such action has been received from Indian Affairs.

R.K. Odell, Esq.,
Chief Administrative Officer,
Administration and Personnel Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Langevin Block,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In his memorandum dated March 16th to our Deputy Minister, the Director of Indian Affairs indicated a degree of urgency regarding purchase of the lighting plant, and if available funds are to be used approval must be given in the next few days.

It is the opinion of this office, nevertheless, that if purchase of the unit can be deferred without endangering the heating plant of the school, and as a result, the health of the pupils and staff, the time should be taken to investigate the matter thoroughly.

T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

RESOLUTION

At Resolution the Roman Catholic Mission erected a new school building, which has only been occupied a year. An addition is shortly to be added, which will make it the largest building north of Edmonton in Treaty 8 District.

At present it is three stories high: a main building measuring 40 x 30; and two of 20 x 40 each. It is an exceedingly well-built frame structure, with a good stone foundation.

The ground floors of both wings are used as class rooms: the second floor of one wing is the chapel, with the dome obliterating the third floor. The second floor of the other wing is the recreation room, and the third floor the girls dormitories. The boys dormitory is the third floor of the main building.

The building is on the whole, well divided, though the staircases are a little dark, and pretty narrow and steep. However, there are outside staircases descending from the dormitories and recreation rooms, so there is practically no danger of accident in case of fire.

The ventilation of dormitories and class rooms has been well attended to. The windows open at both top and bottom, and are so arranged that a good current...
Resolution con.

air can be obtained at any time. Doors open onto spacious galleries from dormitories, class rooms and recreation rooms. Eight large windows in each of the above rooms give ample light; coal oil lamps, of course, are used at night.

The class rooms are equipped with two blackboards, two maps. Three long desks accommodate twenty four pupils; the rest sit at long tables. They are in need of a geography globe; two maps each of the world, the Dominion of Canada and the North Country. They need also two blackboards and brushes, and a couple dozen slates.

The Department last year sent in 25 iron bedsteads and springs but no mattresses. Each child now has four good blankets and a feather pillow. They have of course, their individual towel, comb and basin.

They require a dozen ordinary tubs; and if possible a dozen iron bedsteads.

Water is supplied from a well under the kitchen and is pumped to the kitchen and the girls dormitory. I understand that when the new wing is built, a system of pumps will be extended to the rest of the main rooms.

Two rooms are reserved as infirmaries, one for the boys, one for the girls. They were not used this year, as there was not a single case of illness.

Two cellars 40 x 16; 18 x 16 both 8 feet high and joined by a passage 22 x 4 keep the building from dampness. These are neither floored or walled as yet but that will be attended to later on. The cellars are used as store rooms and contain also two large hot air furnaces which give every satisfaction.
Resolution con.

Besides the school building there are two ice houses, two store houses, one barn two closets, a large house for the priests and one now used as a store house, formerly the old school.

The stock comprises five milch cows, four oxen and two spring calves.

The garden is good. The soil seems to be exceptionally fertile, and under systematic cultivation, yields a surprising crop of vegetables. About four acres are under garden at present, but this area is steadily being added to. This year's crop of vegetables included beans, peas, turnips, onions, cabbage, cauliflower, carrots and tomatoes, which latter, however, did not ripen on the vine, though they grow to a fair size. Cucumbers and squashes were tried without success; but last autumn saw close on to four hundred bushels of potatoes in the store houses.

The grounds around the school building are kept clean and tidy. The building itself is on high ground; and the hundred yards between it and the lake have been cleared, so that the school is the most prominent landmark at Resolution, and I would strongly recommend that the present grant be materially increased. The accommodation will be greatly increased by the erection of the new wing to be occupied next autumn. This wing is to be 22 x 50: three stories high, and will contain three large class rooms. This will necessitate purchasing blackboards, desks, maps, a globe, etc. The present rooms are not too extravagantly equipped in these respects, to say nothing of providing equipment for three more rooms.

Regular fire and military drill vary a curriculum which follows strictly along the lines set down by the Department. The boys help in the garden, and with the wood and furnaces; the girls do all the sewing and knitting for the school. Each girl over twelve takes her turn in the kitchen for a month, and at the end of that time they have learned to do all the cooking for the children's refectory. The food is as good and as plentiful as could be desired anywhere in civilization.

For fire protection as stated before, there are outside stairways from the dormitories, class rooms and recreation rooms. There are also two chemical engines provided by the Department, and pails of water are always ready and filled in convenient places.

Sir:

I have the honor to report upon the condition of the Indian (Roman Catholic) Boarding School at Fort Resolution, Great Slave Lake, which I visited, accompanied by Dr. A. L. MacDonald, the Department's Medical Officer, upon the 5th inst.

This School is conducted by the Grey Nuns, and is under the direct supervision of Bishop Bregman. The building, which is a frame one, three stories high, consists of a main building, 40 x 70, with a wing at either end, 30 x 40; it fronts upon the lake, with a well kept and fertile garden between; all kinds of vegetables and flowers were in a flourishing condition and totally unharmed by frost.

There are seventy-five pupils, who appear to be, as a rule, healthy bright children. The sanitary arrangements are excellent, and cleanliness is evident, both in the persons of the children and in every department of the building. There is a well equipped laundry, and the kitchen is large and well appointed; the dormitories are clean, well ventilated and comfortable, and the heating arrangements are ample, consisting of a large basement wood-heater with radiators.

I would recommend that fire escapes be provided for the upper stories.

EXTRACT FROM THE ANNUAL REPORT OF INSPECTOR H.A. CONROY ON THE SCHOOLS IN TREATY..S., for the year ending March 31st, 1916.

RESOLUTION BOARDING SCHOOL...........

A considerable addition has been recently made to the buildings of the Resolution school, comprising a large wing, 35' by 65' in length. Accommodation is now provided for 75 scholars and the ventilation, heating and dormitory arrangements are everything to be desired.

A good supply of water is provided by a well in the kitchen of the school, although the water from Great Slave Lake is excellent for drinking purposes.

The general school equipment is a little lacking in some respects, especially blackboards, maps, class-books, desks, etc.

At the time of inspection there were 17 boys and 83 girls at the school and all exhibited a well cared for appearance. The proficiency of the scholars was well up to the standard, especially with regard to writing and reading.

The boys have been receiving physical and military drill at the hands of C. Stephens of the R.N.W.M.P. at Resolution and take a keen interest in the training.

The girls receive instruction in housekeeping and needlework and many articles, such as dresses, moccasins and fancy work of caribou and deerskin were to be seen.

Nearly four acres of land in the vicinity of the school are given up to gardening and the different crops of vegetables and roots are sufficient for the upkeep of the school. Facilities are provided for the boys to take part in the fishery and trapping with a view to preparing them to earn their livelihood after leaving the school. The health of the scholars was in every way satisfactory, for, although two rooms in the school have been set aside as infirmaries for the boys and girls they are very rarely occupied.

RESOLUTION BOARDING SCHOOL (Roman Catholic)

This large school is now well able to accommodate 75 scholars, as the right wing has been completed.

The school itself is perhaps one of the most up-to-date, and the ventilating and heating arrangements are everything to be desired. The water supply is derived from a well on the school premises.

At the time of my visit the pupils were having vacation. The total number of pupils at the school at this time was 47.

The school dormitories are light and airy and the general living rooms provide ample space for the requirements. Spacious playgrounds are also provided.

There is a certain amount of laxity in the manner in which Indian children are brought into the schools from their homes. No medical inspection is made and at the time of my visit to Resolution, a band of no less than 14 children of the Dog Rib tribe was brought all the way from Fort Rae in an open York boat and admitted to the school without an inspection. In my opinion there is a considerable risk attached to such conduct, as any contagious disease once contracted by the pupils would be very hard to check or eradicate.

At present the standard of health is very good.

A list of the present pupils and a record of the ex-pupils is attached.

MEMORANDUM

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Rt. Rev. G. Breynat, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie River Diocese, forwards a statement regarding the loss sustained by the Indian residential schools in his Diocese during the past three years as a result of the damage to the boats and fishing gear used by the schools through exceptionally stormy weather. These schools are located at Fort Resolution and Providence Mission.

In order to obtain food supplies for the use of the pupils and staff, which consist principally of fish, the boats and fishing gear had to be immediately replaced, thus entailing an extraordinary and unforeseen expenditure. His Lordship states that an expenditure of $7450 was incurred in replacing the boats and nets, and he requests that some financial assistance be granted to recoup him.

His Lordship asks that the unearned portion of the per capita grants provided for these schools for the present fiscal year be applied towards this purpose. This unearned grant represents the difference between the amount provided in our estimates for each of these schools and the amount of the grant as actually paid, which latter is calculated on the average attendance as shown by the quarterly returns.

The returns for each of the quarters of the present fiscal year are not to hand, but, based on those received, it is estimated that there will be approximately $3000 of unearned grant at the end of the present fiscal year. There was a falling off in the pupilage enrolled at each school occasioned chiefly by sickness among the Indians, and, as a result, there was a lower number of pupils in residence at each school than the per capita grant is provided for. The schools did not, on that account, receive the full grant provided by our appropriation for Indian education.

His Lordship's request is an unusual one, but, owing to the difficulties encountered in conducting these schools, and the cost of their maintenance in this northern country, I am disposed to favourably consider the Bishop's request, and recommend for your approval that at the end of the present fiscal year we transfer the unearned portion of the per capita grants for these two schools towards the cost of reimbursing the church authorities for the expenditure incurred by them in replacing the boats and fishing gear lost through the exceptionally stormy weather.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Mr. Moran, of the Northwest Territories Branch, Department of the Interior, has shown me their files with reference to hospital wings in the Fort Resolution and Hay River Indian Residential Schools. That Department has refused to designate these schools as hospitals, the Department of Health having advised them that it would be "an extremely dangerous situation to set up. Children are potential subjects of all of the infectious diseases, and during such an outbreak a school seems to me to be contrary to all the recognized principles of health protection. I certainly think a hospital (separate building) is required and should be insisted upon." On the grounds, the Interior Department are not paying grants for the hospitalization of patients being treated at the Fort Resolution or Hay River Indian Residential Schools.

Our Department is allowing grants for patients at both schools (Files Nos. 74-139 and 50-139). The Department has written to Dr. Bourget, the Indian agent, regarding the advisability of keeping a patient with an infectious disease at the Hay River School. As a matter of policy, should we allow hospital patients in our residential schools? There is no question but what the authorities of the schools were prompted solely by charity, as they have kept this patient for 24 years without grant.

I presume that the Interior Department will probably cooperate with us in the provision of funds and in the erection of hospital which may be found necessary in the Northwest Territories. The present discussion leads me to believe that a hospital to be constructed either under Royal tax or state surplus funds could be established at Hay River, where the land is suitable for gardening. Further, it appears that Fort Resolution requires a hospital and this fact was brought to our attention by Mr. Lord Bishop Breynat in October, 1923 (114-145). There is a physician at Resolution but not at Hay River. Bishop Breynat's scheme was a combined residential school and hospital, which was changed eventually and which would certainly not be a proper arrangement.

If funds are provided by either the Department of the Interior or this Department, or by both, the Department of Health would submit plans for suitable buildings.

This memorandum has been written, following Mr. Moran's visit, in the interests of the health of the Indian children in residential schools and in the interests of all members of communities who require hospital treatment.

Supt. of Indian Education.
I have the honour to report on conditions of the Agency during the month of November 1925.

An inspection of all the classes was made, and good progress appreciated at Resolution. Even in the youngsters the way they learn the language is very encouraging, showing good talent in the children and patience from the teacher's part.

The children, new comers this year, were immunized against diphtheria, during the month of November, keeping all the school children safe against that disease.

The winter promises to be hard for the Indians and old people especially. The rabbits are very scarce, the ptarmigans were also few this fall, and apparently the fur animals are not getting much food, mice which were so numerous last year are not seen this fall, either extint or migrated.

The mode of living of the Indians in this country is changing with time and, they now have ambition to build houses, and possess gas boats, leaving all the old industries of building canoes aside, and I often wonder if industrial school should not be more important than the teaching of English, French grammar and Geography, etc.

The knowledge of one language takes the rest of the time devoted exclusively to teaching some thing that would be practicable to the Indians would make them more self dependent and it seems to me the style of education would appeal more to the Indians. Certain branches of industry specially adapted to their needs with the idea of improving their abilities in making a living. Their talent is good and they have good ability in carpenter's work, mechanical talent well on the way to progress, and if science could be brought in their way of fishing, trapping and even stock raising or "fur farming" could do a great deal towards the improvement of their life. As soon as they leave school, under present conditions they have no means of keeping in touch with what they have learnt, and forget everything in no time; besides they are handicapped when trying to make their living, and this is the fear of the Indians when sending their children to school. Only very few positions on interpreters are needed and the supply is always great. Of course the knowledge of the two languages is an asset to a man, but their time in school is too short for them to learn from the beginning the two languages then well enough to remember them well, so that if one was learnt well, and all other time devoted to industries for their living, they would be better equipped for life, from their point of view.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit to the Department, for consideration, a question that Bishop Breynat, since his return from the Arctic, asked us to give our attention to.

The point relates to the possibility, in the near future that the Department may consider to take in treaty quite a few of our half breeds of Resolution, Rae and others and in that event, the number of children admitted to our Indian school, specially of Resolution, will be increased, or at least the proportion under our Department care should be augmented, and Bishop Breynat asked us if the time was not suitable to increase the grant of children, from sixty, as at present, to about ninety. We promised to submit this important question to the Department immediately, so that the scheme change may be effected when the half Breeds are taken under the treaty protection. We hope that we are not too late, if the Department views are favorable to that increase of the grant.

The size of the building at Resolution would speak in favor of this innovation. The school is large, substantially built, and can accommodate that number of children, and be within the desirable amount.

There are three large dormitories, two for girls, one for boys, and two class rooms, one of which is rather large, and the other, smaller, is only for the beginners. Each dormitory has a fire exit direct outside, and the dimensions of each are submitted:

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on my visit to St. Joseph's R. C. School at Fort Resolution.

At the time of my visit there were 75 children present, although it was holiday-time, and no school was being operated.

They keep a few cattle and do a little farming, and the following is the stock that is kept there: 6 oxen, 3 horses, 10 cows and 6 other young cattle. The farm consists of 40 acres where oats are planted and also a large garden.

The main building of this school was erected in 1908, and has been added to periodically since that time. It is situated in the Fort, and is right near the lake, and they depend entirely on driftwood for their firewood.

They keep a few cattle and do a little farming, and the following is the stock that is kept there: 6 oxen, 3 horses, 10 cows and 6 other young cattle. The farm consists of 40 acres where oats are planted and also a large garden.

August 9, 1947.

Mr. Meikle

Re - Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School

I inspected the above mentioned school on June 7th and 8th, examined the building and observed the instruction given by the staff.

Representatives of the Mission informed me that the school building is quite inadequate and should be replaced as soon as possible. After checking the building carefully I concur in this view. The building presents a real fire hazard. The foundation is decayed and heaved. The class rooms are small and unhealthy. It is therefore recommended that the replacement of this building be an item on the Educational Building Program for the Northwest Territories.

I encountered considerable criticism of the school on the part of Residents of the Settlement. Many complained that the children were not learning very much by attendance. While such statements are not uncommon wherever a school is functioning, I do feel that a good deal of such criticism could be mitigated by making the instruction in each class more practical and vocational. For example, the instructional program in every school ought to include some training in sewing, home economics, woodwork, leather craft, motor mechanics and machine shop practice. I have endeavoured to make an immediate start in this direction, and instructions have been issued to Mr. L.E. Drummond, Departmental Agent, to send forward to the various Residential schools in the Territories a bundle of mixed woods together with a kit of tools to be used in working same.

The members of the teaching staff are as follows:

Sister Edna Gagnon - holds a Model Diploma for the Province of Quebec, and has 13 years teaching experience. She teaches Grade 1 and 2, and has 23 Residential pupils and 16 Day school pupils, making a total enrolment of 41. Attendance at the time of the visit was 23, most of whom were beginners. The teacher is conscientious and interested in her work. The reading is very good, the writing is excellent, and the pupils are making good progress in their number work.
Sister Marguerite Bourlai - holds no teaching certificate but has fifteen years experience. She teaches Grades 1 and 2, has 25 Residential pupils and 16 day school pupils, making a total enrolment of 41. There were 29 pupils in attendance at the time of the visit. I examined some of the hand work being done by the pupils, listened to their reading, and enjoyed the singing.

Sister Oliva Lavoie - holds a second class permanent Alberta Certificate and has taught for 19 years. She has Grades 3 to 6. The total pupilage is 125, made up of 78 Residential and 47 day school pupils. The school is equipped with a silent film projector. It does not receive Radio Broadcasts. The children received a medical examination and are X-rayed for T.B. on their arrival at school. They also received Dental and Eye examinations. This teacher is very industrious. The children's notebooks were exceptionally good.

The teachers in the Territories quite understandably are not familiar with the enterprise method of education now being used so successfully in the Provinces. Its most valuable feature is that it encourages and trains the children in self expression. On subsequent visits I hope that there will be an opportunity to discuss this method fully with the teachers at the various settlements.

I would suggest that this school be furnished with a good set of Basic Readers. These are required in order that the native children may learn to read by the use of the most modern technique. The teachers have requested readers, knitting wool, prints for making aprons and dresses, and a sound film projector.

The teachers at these schools complain of the poor attendance and feel that some measures should be taken to remedy the condition. They feel that some authority other than the church should impress upon the parents the importance of sending a child to school. The teachers feel that school attendance is an important means of fighting the spread of T.B. They say housing conditions are very poor and that in many cases families are living on a starvation level.

J.W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total No. of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate No. of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total No. of days in quarter."

9. The amount of per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
